div.l: (base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle
(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
(base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde
(base) But o cours / with a sharp ygrounde spere
(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aftꝰer here degre
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
(base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon
(base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
(base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede
(base) Out brest the blood / with sterne stremys rede
(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun
(base) And he hym hurteth / with his hors adoun
(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
(base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
(base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
(base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Some hadde saluys made for the nones
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght

Here begynnyth þe ꝓprolog of þe Myller
When that þe knyȝt hath þus his tale told
In alle þat Cumpanye nas þer ȝong ne old
That he ne saide hit nas a noble storie
And worthi for to drawen in memorie
And namely þe gentilys euerychon
Oure ost louwȝ and sware by seyn Iohan
This goth a riȝt þe game is wel by gone
Now tellith ȝe sir monke ȝyf ȝe conne
Some what to quyte the knyȝtes tale
The Mylward start forth dronken and al pale
So þat vnnethes vpon his hors he sat
He nold auale nother hode ne hat
Ne a bide noman for his curtesye
But in pilatys vois he con crye
And swore by armes and blode and bones
I con a noble tale for the nones
With the wiche I wolle ȝow quyte þe knyȝtes tale
Oure ost sauȝe he was dronken of ale
And said a biden Robyn leue brother
Some beter man shal telle vs first another
A bide and let vs wirke thiftly
By goddes soule ꝙquod he þat wol not I
For I wolle speke or elles go my way
Oure vnswarid telle on a deuelway
Thow art a fool þi witte is ouꝰer come
Now herkenyth ꝙquod þe meller alle and some
But first I make a protestacion
That I am dronke I know it by my sone
And therfore if I mysspeke or say
Wit hit þe Ale of sothewerke I ȝow pray
For I wil tellen a legent and a lif
Both of a Carpenter and of his wif
The Reue vnswarid and saide stynt thy clap
Thow is euyr as dronken as a tappe
Let be thyn lewit dronken halotrye
It is a synne and ekene a grete foly
To apairen anyman or hym defame
And eken to bryng wyfes in sucle blane
Thow maist I nowȝ of other thynges sayn
This dronken Myller spake ful sone a ȝayne

(base) And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
(base) To bedde wente the doghter right anon

div.l: (base) To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
(base) Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
(base) This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale
(base) That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleep
(base) Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
(base) His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
(base) Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong
(base) The wenche routeth eek per compaignye
(base) Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye
(base) He poked Iohn and seyde slepest thow
(base) Herd thow euere slyk a sang er now
(base) Lo swilk a couplyng is ymel hem alle
(base) A wilde fyr on thair bodyes falle
(base) Wha herkned euere swilk a ferly thyng
(base) Ye they sal haue the flour of il endyng
(base) This lang nyght ther tydes me na reste
(base) But yet na force al sal be for the beste
(base) For Iohn seyde he als euere moot I thryue
(base) If that I may yon wenche wol I swyue
(base) Som esement has lawe shapen vs
(base) For Iohn ther is a lawe that says thus
(base) That gif a man in a point be agreued
(base) That in another he sal be releued
(base) Oure corn is stoln soothly it is na nay
(base) And we han had an ille fit to day
(base) And syn I sal haue naan amendement
(base) Agayn my los I wil haue esement
(base) By goddes saule it sal naan other be
(base) This Iohn answerde Aleyn auyse thee
(base) The Millere is a perilous man he sayde
(base) And if that he out of his sleep abrayde
(base) He myghte doon vs bathe a vileynye
(base) Aleyn answerde I counte hym noght a flye
(base) And vp he rist and by the wenche he crepte
(base) This wenche lay vp righte and faste slepte
(base) Til he so neigh was er she myghte espie

div.l: (base) That it hadde been to late for to crie
(base) And shortly for to seyn they were at oon
(base) Now pley Aleyn for I wol speke of Iohn
(base) This Iohn lith stille a furlang wey or two
(base) And to hym self he maketh routhe and wo
(base) Allas quod he this is a wikked Iape
(base) Now may I seyn that I is but an ape
(base) Yet has my felawe som what for his harm
(base) He has the Milleris doghter in his arm
(base) He auntred hym and has his nedes sped
(base) And I lye as a draf sak in my bed
(base) And whan this iape is told another day
(base) I sal ben halden a daf a Cokenay
(base) I wil arise and auntre it by my fayth
(base) Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
(base) And vp he roos and softely he wente
(base) Vn to the Cradel and in his hand it hente
(base) And baar it softe vn to his beddes feet
(base) Soone after this the wyf hir routynt leet
(base) And gan awake and wente hir out to pisse
(base) And cam agayn and gan hir Cradel mysse
(base) And groped heer and ther but she foond noon
(base) Allas quod she I hadde almoost mysgoon
(base) I hadde almoost goon to the clerkes bed
(base) Ey benedicite thanne had I foule ysped
(base) And forth she gooth til she the Cradel fond
(base) She gropeth alwey forther with hir hond
(base) And foond the bed and thoghte noght but good
(base) By cause that the Cradel by it stood
(base) And nyste wher sche was for it was derk
(base) And nyste wher she was for it was derk
(base) But faire and wel she creep in to the clerk
(base) And lyth ful stille and wolde haue caught a sleep
(base) With Inne a while this Iohn the clerk vp leep
(base) And on this goode wyf he leyth on soore
(base) So murie a fyt ne hadde she nat ful yoore
(base) He priketh harde and depe as he were mad
(base) This ioly lyf han thise two clerkes lad
(base) Til that the thridde cok bigan to synge
(base) Aleyn wax wery in the dawenynge

div.l: (base) For he hadde swonken al the longe nyght
(base) And seyde fare wel Malyn swete wight
(base) The day is come I may no lenger byde
(base) But euere mo wher so I go or ryde
(base) I is thyn awen clerk so haue I sel
(base) Now deere lemman quod she go farewel
(base) But er thow go o thyng I wol thee telle
(base) Whan that thow wendest homward by the Melle
(base) Right at the entree of the dore bihynde
(base) Thow shalt a Cake of half a busshel fynde
(base) That was ymaked of thyn owene mele
(base) Which that I heelp my sire for to stele
(base) And good lemman god thee saue and kepe
(base) And with that word almoost he gan to wepe
(base) Aleyn vp rist and thoghte er that it dawe
(base) I wol go crepen In by my felawe
(base) And fond the Cradel with his hond anon
(base) By god thoghte he al wrang I haue mysgon
(base) Myn heed is toty of my swynk to nyght
(base) That maketh me that I go noght aright
(base) I woot wel by the Cradel I haue mysgo
(base) Here lyth the Millere and his wyf also
(base) And forth he gooth on twenty deueleway
(base) Vn to the bed ther as the Millere lay
(base) He wende haue cropen by his felawe Iohn
(base) And by the Millere In he creep anoon
(base) And caughte hym by the nekke and softe he spak
(base) He seyde thou Iohn thow swyneshed awak
(base) For cristes saule and here a noble game
(base) For by that lord that called is Seint Iame
(base) As I haue thries in this shorte nyght
(base) Swyued the Milleris doghter bolt vp right
(base) Whil thow hast as a coward been agast
(base) Ye false harlot quod the Millere hast
(base) Ye false harlot hast thou so hest
(base) A false traytour false clerk quod he
(base) Thou shalt be deed by goddes dignytee
(base) Who dorste be so bold to disparage
(base) My doghter that is come of swich lynage
(base) And by the throte bolle he caughte Alayn

div.l: (base) And he hente hym despitously agayn
(base) And on the nose he smoot hym with his fest
(base) Doun ran the blody streem vp on his brest
(base) And on the floor with nose and mouth tobroke
(base) They walwen as doon two pigges in a poke
(base) And vp they goon and doun agayn anoon
(base) Til that the Millere sporned on a stoon
(base) And doun he fil bakward vp on his wyf
(base) That wiste no thyng of this nyce stryf
(base) For she was falle aslepe alitel wight
(base) With Iohn the clerk that waked hadde al nyght
(base) And with the fal out of hir sleep she brayde
(base) Help holy cros of Bromholm she sayde
(base) In manus tuas lord to thee I calle
(base) Awake Symond the feend is on me falle
(base) Myn herte is broken help I nam but ded
(base) Ther lyth oon vp on my wombe and vp myn hed
(base) Help Symkyn for the false clerkes fighte
(base) This Iohn sterte vp as faste as euere he myghte
(base) And graspeth by the walles to and fro
(base) To fynde a staf and she sterte vp also
(base) And knew the estres bet than dide this Iohn
(base) And by the wal a staf she foond anon
(base) And saugh a litel shymeryng of a light
(base) For at an hole in shoon the moone bright
(base) And by that light she saugh hem bothe two
(base) But sikerly she nyste who was who
(base) But as she saugh a whit thyng in hir Iye
(base) And whan she gan this white thyng espye
(base) She wende the clerk hadde wered a voluper
(base) And with the staf she drow ay ner and ner
(base) And wende han hit this Aleyn at the fulle
(base) And smoot the Millere on the piled skulle
(base) That doun he gooth and cryde harrow I dye
(base) Thise clerkes bette hym wel and lete hym lye
(base) And greithen hem and tooke hir hors anon
(base) And eek hir mele and on hir wey they gon
(base) And at the Mille yet they toke hir cake
(base) Of half a busshel flour ful wel ybake
(base) Thus is the proude Millere wel ybete
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And hath ylost the gryndyng of the whete
(base) And payed for the souper euerydel
(base) Of Aleyn and of Iohn that bette hym wel
(base) His wyf is swyued and his doghter als
(base) Lo which it is a Millere to be fals
(base) And therfore this prouerbe is seyd ful sooth
(base) Hym thar nat wene wel that yuele dooth
(base) A gilour shal hym self bigiled be
(base) And god that sitteth heighe in magestee
(base) Saue al this compaignie grete and smale
(base) Thus haue I quyt the Millere in my tale
(base) Here endeth the Reues tale
by gynnyth þe prolog of þe Cookes tale
The coke of london while þe Reue spake
For Ioy hym þought he clowed hym on þe bake
Ha ha qd he for cristes passion
This Miller hath a sharp conclusion
Vppon his argument of herbigage
Wel seide Salamon in his langage
Ne bryng not euꝰery man in to þyn hous
For herberwyng be nyght is ꝑperlous
Wel oughte a man auysed for to be
Whom þat he brought in to his piriuyte
I pray to god so ȝeue me sorow ⁊ kare
If euer sithen I hight hogge of ware
Herd I a Miller better y sette a werke
He hadde a Iape of malice in þe derke
And therfore if ȝe vouchesaf to here
But god for bede þat we stynt here
A tale of me þat am a pore man
I wil ȝow telle as wel as euꝰer I can
A litul Iape þat fel in oure Cite
Oure oost vnswarid and said I garante it þe
Now telle on Roger loke þat it be gode
For mony a pastay hast þow let blode
And mony a Iacke of douer hast þow sold
That hath I ben twyes hoot ⁊ twyes cold
Of mony a pilgrym hast thow cristes cors
For of þi persely ȝet þei fare þe wors
That þei han Eten with þe stoppit goos
For in þi shope is mony a flye loos
Now telle on gentel Roger by thy name
But ȝet I pray the be noȝt wroth for game
Thow saist ful soth ꝙquod Roger by my faith
But sooth play what play this þe flemyng saith
And therfore henry bailly by thi faith
Be þow nouȝt wroth er we deꝑperten here
Thei thaugh my tale be of an Oostlere
But natheles I wolle not telle it ȝet
But er I parte I wys þow shalt be quyte
And ther with al he lough and made chere
And said his tale as ȝe shul after here
Here endith þe ꝓprolog of þe Cokes tale
and here begynnyth þe tale
A Prentise whilom dwellid in oure Cite
And of a craft of vitailes was he
Gailard he was as goldfynche in shawe
Bron as a bery ꝓproper short felowe
With lokkes blake I kempt ful fetously
Daunce he couthe wel and Iolyly
Þat he was clopen perkyn þe Reuelour
He was as ful of loue and ꝑperamour
As is þe hyue ful of hony swete
Wel was þe wenche þat with hym myȝt mete
At euꝰery bridale wold he frike and hoppe
He louet bet þe tauerne than þe shoppe
For when þer eny ridyng was in shepe
Out of þe shop þider wole he lepe
Til þat he had alle þat sight I seyn
And daunced wel he nold come agayn
And gedrid hym a meny of his sort
To hoppe and syng ⁊ make suche disport
And ther þei setten steuen for to mete
To pleyn at þe dees in suche a strete
For in þe toūn þer nas no prentis
Þat fairer couth caste a pere dys
Then ꝑperkyn couth and ther to he was fre
Of his dispence in place of piriuyte
That fond his maister wel in his chaffare
For oft tyme he fond his box al bare
For sicurly a prentis reueilour
That hauntith dys ryot or ꝑperamour
His maister shal it in his shoppe a bye
Al haue he no part of þe mynstrasye
For thief and ryot þei ben conuertible
Alconne he play on gyterne or rybible
Reuel and trouth as in a low degre
Þei ben ful wroth al day as men may se
This Ioly prentis with his mayster bode
Til he were out nyȝe of his prentis hode
Alle were he snybbid both Erly and late
And sumtyme ladd with Reuel to newgate
But atte last his maister hym by thouȝt
Vpon a day when he his pauꝑper souȝt
Of a prouer be þat saith þis same word
Wel beter is roten appel out of hord
Then þat he roten al þe remenaūnt
So farith it by a riotes seruaunt
Hit is ful lase harme to lete hym passe
Then he shend all þe seruaūntes in the place
Ther fore his maister ȝef hym a quitance
And bade hym go with sorow and myschance
Alle þus þis Ioly prentis hath his leue
Now lete hym ryot alle þe nyȝt or leue
And for ther nys no theof with outen a louke
That helpith hym to wast and to souke
Of þat he brybe con or borow may
A noon he sent his bed and his aray
Vn to a conper of his ow sorte
That louyd dys reuel and disporte
And hade a wif þat hele for contynaunce
A shoppe and swyuet for hur sustynaunce
But herof I wolle passe as now
Here begynnyth the Cokys tale
Lithen and lystenytk and herkenyth arigt
And ye shul heren of a doughty knyght
Syr Iohn of Boundis was his name
He coude of norture and mochel of game
Thre sones the knyght had and with his body he hem wan
The eldest was a moche shrewe and sone he began
His brothern loued wele hir Fader and of hym were agast
The eldest deserued his Faders curs and had it at last
The good knyght his Fader leued so yore
That deth was comen hym and handlyd hym ful sore
The good knyght cared sore sike there he lay
How his children shuld lyuen after his day
He hadde ben wyde where but noon husbond he was
Alle the londe that he had it was verrey purchas
Fayn he wolde it were drissed amonge hem alle
That iche of hem had his part as it myght falle
Thoo sent he into the contre after wyse knyghtes
To helpe delen his londes and dressen hem to rightes
He sente hem worde by lettres to highe blyve
Yf they wolde speke with hym while he was on lyve
The knyghtes herden seke that he lay
Had they no reste neyther nyght ne day
Til they comen to hym ther he lay stille
On his dethbedde to abyde goddes wille
Than seyde the good knyght sike ther he lay
Lordes I yow warne forsothe withouten nay
I may no lenger leve here in this stounde
For though goddes wille deth draweth me to grounde
Ther nas noon of hem alle that harde hym aright
That thay hadden routhe of that ilke knyght
And seyde sire forgoddis loue dismay yow nought
God may don bote of bale that is now I wrought
Than spak the good knyght sike ther he lay
Bote of bale god may sende I wote it is no nay
But I beseke yow knyghtes for the loue of me
Gooth and dresseth my londes amonge my sones thre
And for the loue of god deleth hem not amys
And forgete not Gamelyn my yonge son that is
Taketh heed he to that oon as wele as to that other
Selde ye see any Eier helpen his brother
Thoo leten they the knyght lyen that was nat in hele
And wenten into consel his londes footo dele
For to delen hem alle to oon that was her thought
And For Gamelyn was yongest he sholde haue nought
Alle the londe that ther was they dalten it in twoo
And lete Gamelyn the yonge with outen londe goo
And eche of hem saide til other ful loude
His brothern mowe yeve hym londe when he good coude
Whan they had delyd the londe at hire owne wille
They come to the knyght ther he lay ful stille
And tolde hym anoon how they hadde wrought
And the knyght ther he lay lyked it right nought
Than seyde the knyght be seint Martyn
For al that ye haue don yet is the lond myn
For goddes loue neighbours stondeth alle stille
And I wole delen myn lond at myn owen wille
Iohn myn Eldest sone shal haue plowes fyve
That was my faders heritage while he was on lyve
And my myddelest sone fyve plowes londe
That I halpe to geten with my right honde
And alle my other purchas of londes and ledes
That I be quethe Gamelyn and alle my good stedes
And I beseke yow good men that lawe kan of londe
For Gamelynes loue that my quest stonde
Thus dalt the knyght his londe by his day
Right on his deth bedde sike ther he lay
And sone afterwarde he lay stone stille
And deide whan tyme come as it was cristis wille
Anoon as he was deed and vnder gras graue
Sone the eldere brothere bygiled the yonge knaue
He toke into his hoond his londe and his lede
And Gamelyn hym silfe to clothe and to fede
He clothed hym and fedde hym wel and eke wroth
And lete his londes forfare and his houses both
His parkes and his wodes and did nothyng wel
And sithen he hit aboughte in his faire fel
So longe was Gamelyn in his brothers halle
For the strengest of good wille thei doutide hym alle
Ther was noon ther Inne noyꝰer yonge ne olde
That wolde wrath Gamelyn were he neuer so bolde
Gamelyn stood on a day in his brotheres yerde
And bygan with his honde to handelyn his berde
He thought on his londes that layn vnsawe
And his faire Okes that doun were drawe
His Park were broken and his dere reued
Of alle his good stedes noon was hym byleued
Hise houses were vnhelyd and fulle Ille dight
Thoo thought Gamelyn it went nought a right
Aftirward cam his brother walkyng thare
And saide to Gamelyn is our mete yare
Tho Gamelyn wrathed hym and swore by goddes boke
Thow shalt goo bake thy selfe I wil not be thy coke
How brother Gamelyn answerst thow now
Thow spak neuer suche a worde as thow dost now
By my faith saide Gamelyn now me thenketh nede
Of alle the harmes that I haue I toke neuer are hede
Myn parkes ben broken and my dere ben reved
Of my Armure and my stedes nought is beleued
Alle that my fader me bequath al goth to shame
And therfore haue thow goddes curs brother be thy name
Than bespak his brother that rape was of rees
Stonde stille Gadlyng and holde right thy pees
Thow shalt be fayn forto haue thy mete and thy wede
What spekest thow Gamelyn of londe oyꝰer of lede
Than saide Gamelyn the childe that was ying
Cristis curs mote he haue that clepeth me gadlyng
I am no wors gadlyng ne no wors wight
But born of a lady and geten of a knyght
Ne durst he not to Gamelyn oo foot goo
But cleped to hym his men and saide to hem thoo
Gooth and beteth this boy and reueth hym his wit
And late hym lere another tyme to answere me bet
Than saide the childe yonge Gamelyn
Cristis curs mote thow haue brother art thow myn
And if I shal algate be beten anoon
Cristis curs mote thow haue but thow be that oon
And anon his brother in that grete hete
Made his men to fette stauys Gamelyn to bete
Whan euer y of hem hadde a staffe I nomen
Gamelyn was ware thoo he saugh hem comen
Tho Gamelyn seigh hem comen he loked ouer al
And was ware of a pestel stode vnder a walle
Gamelyn was light and theder gan he lepe
And drofe alle his brothers right sone on hepe
He loked as a wilde lyon and leyd on good wone
Tho his brother say that he bygan to gone
He Flygh vp in til a lofte and shet the dore fast
Thus Gamelyn with his pestel made hem alle agast
Some for Gamelyns loue and som for his eie
Alle they drowen by halfes thoo he gan to pleie
What now seid Gamelyn euel mote ye the
Wille ye bygynne contek and so sone fle
Gamelyn sought his brother whither he was flowe
And saugh where he loked oute atte a wyndowe
Brother saide Gamelyn come a litel nere
And I wille teche the a playe atte bokelere
His brother hym answerde and swore by seint richere
While the pestel is in thyn honde I wil come no nere
Brother I wille make thy pees I swere by cristis ore
Caste a way the pestel and wrath the nomore
I mote nedes saide Gamelyn wrath me attones
For thow wolde make thy men to breke my bones
Ne hadde I hadde mayn and myght in my armes
To haue hem froo me they wolde don me harmes
Gamelyn saide to his brother be thow not wroth
Forto sen the haue harme me were right loth
I ne dede it not brother but for a fondyng
For to loke if thow were stronge and art so ying
Come adoun than to me and graunt me my bone
Of thynge I wille asken the and we shulle saughte sone
Doun than come his brother that fikel was and felle
And was sweith sore agaste of the pestelle
He saide brother Gamelyn aske me thy bone
And loke thow me blame but I it graunte sone
Than saide Gamelyn brother I wisse
And we shalle ben attone thow most me graunte thisse
Alle that my fader me bequath while he was on lyue
Thow most do me it haue if we shulle not stryue
That shalt thow haue Gamelyn by cristis ore
Al that thy fader the bequath though thow woldest haue more
Thy lande that lyeth lay ful wele it shalle be sowe
And thyn houses reysed vp that ben layd so lowe
Thus saide the knyght to Gamelyn be mouthe
And though of falnesse as he wele couthe
The knyght thought on treson and Gamelyn on noon
And wente and kyssed his brother and when they weren atoon
Allas yonge Gamelyn nothynge he ne wyste
With swiche fals treson his brother hym kyste
Lythe and lysteneth and holdeth youre tonge
And ye shulle here talkynge of Gamelyn the yonge
Ther was ther beside cried a wrastlyng
And therfore ther was sette a Ram and a ryng
And Gamelyn was in wille to wende ther too
Forto prouen his myght what he couth doo
Brother saide Gamelyn be seint Richere
Thow most lene me to nyght a lytel coursere
That is freisshe to the spores on for to ride
I moste on an Erand alitel here beside
By god saide his brother of stedes in my stalle
Goo and chese the best spare noon of alle
Of stedes or coursers that stonde hym bysyde
And telle me my brother whedur thow wilt ride
He byside brother is cried a wrastlyng
And therfore shalle besette a Ram and a ryng
Moche worshep it were brother to vs alle
Might I the Ram and the ryng bryngen hom to the halle
A stede ther was sadled smartly an skete
Gamelyn Dide a peire of spores fast on his fete
He sette his fote in the styrope the stede he be strode
And toward the wrastlyng the yonge childe rode
Tho Gamelyn the yonge was riden oute at the gate
The fals knyght his brother loked it after thate
And besought Ihu criste that is heuen kyng
He myght breke his nekke in that wrastlyng
As sone as Gamelyn come ther the place was
He light doun of the stede and stode on the gras
And ther he harde a Frankelyn weloway syng
And bygan bitterly his hondes forto wryng
Gode man saide Gamelyn why makest thow this fare
Ys ther noman may helpen you out of is care
Allas saide this Frankelyn that euer was I bore
For tweie stalworth sones I wene I haue forlore
A champyon is in the place that hath wrought me sorowe
For he hath slayn my too sones but if god hem borowe
I wolde yeue x li by Ihu Crist and more
With the nones I fonde a man to handelyn hym sore
Gode man saide Gamely wilt thow wele done
Holde my hors while my man draweth of my shone
And helpe my man to kepe my clothes and my stede
And I wille into the place and loke how I may spede
By god saide the Frankelyn it shalle bedone
I wille my selfe be thy man to drawe of thy shone
And wende thow into the place Ihu criste the spede
And drede not of thy clothes nor of thy good stede
Barfote and vngyrt Gamelyn in came
Alle that were in the place hede of hym name
How he durste auntre hym to doon his myght

l.seg: But Gamelyn sayd adam do hem but goode

div.l: They ben men of holy chirche drawe of hem no blood

Brother in suche a forward I take hym to the

I graunte wele saide ser Ote that it so be
Late delyuꝰere hym anoon and take hym to me
Tho was Gamelyn delyuꝰered to ser Ote his brother
And that nyght dwelled the toon with the tother
On the morne saide Gamelyn to ser Ote the hende
Brother he saide I forsoth I mote fro the wende
To loke how my yonge men lede her lyfe
Whether they lyfen in Ioye or in stryfe
By god saide ser Ote that is a colde rede
Now I see that alle the Carke shal falle on my hede
For whan the Iustice sitte and thow be not I founde
I shal anoon be take and in thy steed I bounde
Brother saide Gamelyn dismaye the nought
For be seint Iame in Gales yt many man hath sought
If that god almyghty holde me my lyfe and my witte
I wille be there redy whan the Iustice sitte
Than saide ser Ote to Gamelyn god shelde the fro shame
Come whan thow seist tyme and brynge vs oute of blame
Lith and listeneth and holde yow stille
And ye shulle here how Gamelyn had his wille
Gamelyn went vnder wood rise
And fonde there plaiyng yong men of prise
Thoo was yonge Gamelyn right glad Inow
Whan he fonde his men vnder wood bow
Gamelyn and his men talked I fere
And thay had good game hire maister to here
His men tolde hym of aventures that they had founde
A Gamelyn hem tolde ayein how he was faste bounde
While Gamelyn was outlawe had he no curs
Ther was noman that for hym ferde the wurs
But Abbottis and Priours Monke and Chanoun
On hem left he nought whan he myght hem nome
While Gamelyn and his men made myrthes ryue
The fals knyght his brother euel mote he thryue
For he aboute bothe day and other
Forto hire the quest to hangen his brother
Gamelyn stood on a day and he byhelde
The wodes and the shawes in the wild felde
He thought on his brother how he hym behete
That he wolde be redy whan the Iustice sete
He thought wele that he wolde with oute delay
Come afore þe Iustice to keepen his day
Come a fore the Iustice with oute delay
And saide to his yonge men dighteth yow yare
For whan the Iustice sitte we most be thare
For I am vnder borwe til that I come
And my brother for me to prisou shal be nome
Be saint Iame saide his yonge men and thow rede ther to
Ordeyne how it shal be and it shal be doo
While Gamelyn was comyng ther the Iustice satte
The fals knyght his brother forgate he not thatte
To hire then men on his quest to hangen his brother
Thow they hadde not that oon he wolde had that other
Thoo come Gamely fro vnder wood rise
And brought with hym yonge men of prise
I se wele saide Gamelyn the Iustice is sette
Goo a forn Adam and loke how it spette
Adam wente into the halle and loked alle aboute
He sawe stonde there lordes grete and stoute
And ser Otes his brother fetered wele fast
Tho went Adam oute of the halle as he were agast
Adam saide to Gamelyn and to his felawes alle
Sir Ote stant fetered in the mote halle
Yonge men sayde Gamelyn this they heeren alle
Sire Ote stant fetered in the moot hall
Yf god yeue vs grace wele forto doo
He shal it abigge that it brought ther too
Than saide Adam that lokkes had hore
Cristis curs mote he haue that bound hym so sore
And thow wilt Gamelyn don after myn rede
There is non in the halle shal bere a way his heede
Adam saide Gamelyn we wil not doo soo
We wille slee the giltife and lete the other goo
I wille into the halle and here the Iustice speke
On hem that ben gilty I wil ben awreke
Late noon scape atte dore take yonge men yeme
For I wille be Iustice this day domes to deme
God spede me this day at my newe werke
Adam come with me for thow shalt be my clerke
His men answerd hym and bad hym don his best
And if thow to vs haue nede thow shalt fynd vs prest
We wille stande with the while that we may dure
But we werke manly pay vs no hure
Yonge men saide Gamelyn so mote I the
As trusty a maister ye shul fynd of me
Right there the Iustice satte in the halle
Inne went Gamelyn amonge hem alle
Gamelyn lete vnfet ꝰere his brother oute of bende
Than saide ser Ote his brother that was hende
Thow haddist almost Gamelyn dwelled to longe
For the quest is oute of me that I sholde honge
Brother saide Gamelyn so god yeue me good rest
This day thay shul ben hanged that ben on thy quest
And the Iustice bothe that is the Iugge man
And the shiref both thorow hym it began
Than saide Gamelyn to the Iustice
Now is thy power don thow most nedes ryse
Thow hast yeuen domes that ben euel dight
I wille sitten in thi sete and dressen hem aright
The Iustice satte stille and roos not anoon
And Gamelyn cleued his cheke bon
Gamelyn toke hym in his armes and nomore spak
But threwe hym ouer the barre and his arme brak
Durst noon to Gamelyn say but good
For fere of the companye that with oute stode
Gamelyn sette hym doun in the Iustice stede
And sire Otes his broþer by hel and adam at his feet
Whan Gamelyn was sette in the Iustices sete
Herkeneth of borde that Gamelyn the dede
He lete fetere the Iustice and his fals brother
And lete hem come to the barre the toon with that other
Tho Gamelyn hadde thus I doo thoo had he no rest
Til he hadde enquered who was on the quest
Forto demen his brother ser Ote forto honge
Er he wist whiche they were it thought hym ful longe
But as sone as Gamelyn wyst where they were
He dide hem euer ychou fetere in fere
And bryngen hem to the barre and sette hem in rewe
By my faith saide the Iustice the shiref is a sherewe
Than saide Gamelyn to the Iustice
Thow haste yove domes of the worst assise
And thoo twelue sisours that weren of the quest
They shol ben honged to day so god yeue me good rest
Than saide the shiref to yonge Gamelyn
Lorde I crie the mercy brother art thow myn
Therfore saide Gamelyn haue thow cristis curs
For and thow were maister yet shold I fare wurs
For to make short tale and not to longe
He ordeyned hym a quest of his men so stronge
The Iustice and the shiref bothe honged hye
To wemen with the rapes and with the wynd drye
And the xij seisours sorow haue that rekke
Alle they were hanged fast by the nekke
Thus endeth the fals knyght with his trecherie
That euer had lad his lyfe in falsnesse and in folie
He was honged by the necke and not by the purs
That was the mede that he hadde for his faders curs
ser Ote was eldest and Gamelyn was yynge
Wenten with her frendes and passed with the kynge
They made pees with the kyng of the best sise
The kynge loued ser Ote wele and made hym Iustice
And after the kyng made Gamelyn both in Este and West
Chief Iustice of his free Forest
Alle his wight yonge men the kyng forgaf hire gilt
And sithen in good office the kyng had alle hym pilt
Thus wanne Gamelyn his londe and his lede
And wraked hym of his enemyes and quitte hem her mede
And ser Ote his brother made hym his aire
And sithen wedded Gamelyn a wyf good and faire
They lyueden to gider while that criste wolde
And sithen was Gamelyn grauen vnder molde
And so shal we alle may there noman flee
God brynge vs to the Ioye that euer shal be
Explicit fabula de Gamelyn

div.l: (base) ¶ The prohemie of the Mannes tale of Lawe
(base) Ovre hoost saw wel that the brighte sonne

(base) ¶ Lordynges quod he I warne yow al this route

(base) Descendynge fro the montaigne in to playn

(base) It wol nat come agayn / withouten drede
(base) Namoore / than wol Malkyns maydenhede
(base) Whan she hath lost it / in hir wantownesse
(base) Lat vs nat / mowlen thus in ydelnesse
(base) ¶ Sire man of lawe quod he / so haue ye blys
(base) Tel vs a tale anon / as forward is
(base) Ye been submitted / thurgh youre free assent

div.l: (base) To breken forward / is nat myn entente

(base) He sholde hymself / vsen it by right

div.l: (base) But certeinly / no word ne writeth he

(base) Of swiche cursed stories / I sey fy

(base) How that / the cursed kyng Antiochus
(base) Birafte his doghter / of hir maydenhede

div.l: (base) ¶ And bigynneth his tale

Þat selden tyme is founden in mariage
Þer as was fre þingben in seruage
¶ But natheles I se ȝoure trew entente
And truste vpon ȝoure witte and han done aye
Wherof my fre wil I wil assent
To wed me as sone as euer I may
But þer as ȝe haue profered me to day
To chese me a wif I wil relese
Þat choise and pray yow of þat profre cese
¶ For god woot þat children oft ben
Vnlike her worthi eldres hem by forne
Bounte comeþ oft of god noght of þe stren

¶ Late me allone in chesyng of my wif

ꝙquodat what wif I take ȝe me ensure

¶ And forþꝰermore shullen ȝe swere þat ȝe
A . ȝene my choys shullen neuꝰer gruche ne stryve

¶ With hertly wille þei sworen and assent /
To alle þis þing þer seid no wight nay

Þat he wold graunte hem a certeyn / day

¶ And ther vpon he his Officers

¶ Noght fer From þe paleys honorurable
Wher as þis markys Shope his mariage
Þer stode a þroop delitable

Hadden her bestes and her herbegage
And of hir labour toke hire sustynance
Aftir þat þe erthe ȝaf hem habundance
¶ Among þis pore folke duelled aman
Wiche þat was hold porest of hem alle
But hygh god sumtyme Send can
His grace vnto a litul oxe stalle
Ianycula men of þroop hem calle
A . doghter he had faire Inogh to sight
And Grisild þis ȝong maide hight
But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Þan was she on þe fairest vnder sonne
Wel pouerly I fostred was she
No lykerousnes was on hir lust Ironne
Wel ofter of þe welle þan of þe tonne
She dranke and for she wold vertue plese
She knew welle labour but noon ydel Ese
But þogh þis maide were tendre of age
Ȝet in þe brest of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sad Corage
And in grete reuerence and charite
Hir old pouer fader fostred she
A few shepe spynnynge on þe feld she kepte
She wold noght ben ydel til she slepte
¶ And when she homward come she wold brynge
Wortes and herbes tymes ful ofte
Wiche She shrad and seth for hir lyynge
And made hir bed ful hard and no þing softe
And euer she kept hir fader lyue on loft
With euery obeisance and diligence
Þat child may to fadres reuerence
¶ Vpon Griseld þe pore creature
Welle ofte hath markys sette his eye
As he on huntyng roode ꝑperauentre
And whan it felle þat he hir myghte aspie

Comendyng in his hert hir womanhede

For þogh þe peple haue no grete insight
In vertu he considered ful right
Hir beaute and disposid þat he wold
Hir wedd ȝif euꝰer he wedd shold

Wol noght oure lord leue his vanite

¶ But natheles þis markys hath do make
Of gēmmes sette in gold and in azure

Þat to suche a . weddyng shuld falle

Aprocheþ þat þis weddyng shuld be

þat may be fond as fer as lasteþ Itaile
This real marqueys really arrayed
Lordys and ladies in his companye
The weche to þe fest were praied
And of his retenue þe bachelere
With mony a soūn of sondry melodie
Vnto the vilage wiche I told
In þis array þe right way hath hold
¶ Griseld god wote of this ful Innocent
That for hir was shape alle þis aray

And comeþ home as sone as euꝰer she may
For welle she herd saie þat ilke day
Þat markys shuld wedd and if she nyȝt

She þoght I wolle with oþir maydenes stond
Þat ben my felowes in oure dore ⁊ se
The marquys and þerfore wole I fond

Þe labour wiche þat longith to me
And þan may I at leiser it be hold
Ȝif She þis way to þe Castel hold
And as she wold ouer þe þresfold gon

And she sette doūn hir water potte anon
By side þe þresshefold of þe Oxe stalle
And doūn vpon hir knees she con to falle
And with sad contynance kneled stille
Til she had herd what was þe lordes wille
This þoghtful markys spak vn to þis maide
Wel soberly and saide in þis manere
Where is ȝour fadir Grisild he saide
And She with reuꝰerence and meke þe che
Unsward lord he is al redy heere
And in she goth with oute any longꝰer late
And to þe markys she hir fader fette
¶ He by the hond þan toke þis old man
And said þus when he hym had on side
Ianicula I neither may no can
Lenger þe plesance of myn hert hide
Ȝif þat þou vouche sauf what so bitide
Þi doghter wole I take or þat I wende
As for my wif to my lyues ende
¶ Thou louest me I wotte wel certeyne
And art my feithful lige man I bore
And alle þat likith me I dar wel sayne
Hit liketh the and specialy þerfore
Telle me þat poynt þat I haue said to fore
Ȝif þat þou wolt vnto þat purpos draw
To take me as for þyn son in lawe
¶ The sodeyn cas þe man astonyed so
The rede he waxe al basched and alle quakyng
He stode vnnethee ne said wordes moo
But only þus lord quod he my willyng

I wol no þing ȝe be my lord so dere
Right as yow list gouꝰerrneþ þis matere
Than wolle I do þus quod markys softly
That in the chambre I ⁊ þou and she
Haue a collon and wost þou whi
For I wille aske hir ȝif hir wille
To be my wif and rule hir aftir me
And alle þis she shal don in thy pꝰersence

¶ And in the chambre while þei were a boute
Hire tretis wiche ȝe shul aftꝰer here
The peple come in to þe hous wtith out
And wondred hem in honest manꝰer
And tentyfly she kept hir fader dere
But vtterli Griseld wonder myght
For neuꝰer eft say she suche a sight

She was neuer to suche gestes woned
For wiche she lokid with ful pale face
But shortely fro þis mater for to pace
This were þe wordis þat þis markys saide
To þis benigne verray feithful maide
¶ Griseld he saide ȝ wole welle vnderstonde

Þat I ȝow wedd and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose þat ȝe woleþ þat it so be

Þat sithen it shal be don in hastif wise

¶ I seie þis be ȝe redy with good hert
To alle my lust ⁊ þat I frely may

And ȝe neuꝰer gruche nyght ne day
And eke whan I seie ȝe seie ȝe not nay

¶ Wondryng vpon þis word quakyng for drede
She saide lord indigne and vnworthi
Am I to þat þat ȝe me bede

And I swere þat neuer willyngly
In word ne in þoght Ineuꝰer ȝow disobeie

This is I noghe Griseld myn owne quod he
And . forth he goth wit a . sobre chere
Out at þe dore after cam she
And to þe peple he said on þis manere
This is my wif quod stondith here
Honoureþ hir and louyth hir I praye
Who so loueþ me þer is no more to seie
¶ And for no þing of hir old gere
She shule bryng to his hous he bade
Þat wōmman shold spoilen hir right þere
OF wiche þe ladies were not right glad
To handle hir clothes in wiche she was clad
But natheles þis maid bright of hewe

¶ Hire heres han þei kembed þat lay vntressed
Wel rudely with hir fyngres smale
And a crowne on hir heed þei hane dressed
And sette hit ful of ovches grete and smale
Of hir array what shuld I make a tale
Vnneth þe peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she transformed was in suche richesse
¶ This markys hath hir spoused wtith a ryng
Boght for þe same cause . and þen hir sette

¶ And shortly forth þis tale for to chace
I say þat to þis new marquyssesse
God hath I sente suche fauoure of his grace
Þat it semed not as by likenesse
Þat she was borne and Fed in rudenesse

¶ To euꝰery wight she woxen is so dere
And worschipful þat folke þer she was bore

Vnneþ trowed þei but dorst haue swore
Þat to Ianycle of wiche I spake to fore

Hem þoght she was another creature
For þat euꝰer vertuouse was she
She was encresed in suche excellence
Of thewes sette in hyhe bounte
And so descrete and faire of eloquence
So benigne and digne of Reuꝰerence
And coude þe peple hert so embrace
Þat eche hir loued þat loked on hir face
¶ Noght only of Saluce in þe toūn
Publisshed was þe bounte of hir name
And Eke bi side in mony a region
If oon said welle an oþer saide þe same
So sprad of hir boūnte the fame
þat men and wōmmen both ȝong ⁊ olde
Gon to Saluce hir to by hold
¶ This Waltꝰer lowly nay but rially

In goddes pees lyuyth wel Esily
At home and outeward grace I nogh hadde he
And for he sawh vnder low degre

A prudent man and þat is seyn wel seld
Noght only Griseld þus þorgh hir witte
Coude alle þe feete of wifly homblynesse
But eke whan þe cas required it
Þe comine profit coude she redresse
Þer nas discord rancour ne heuynesse

¶ Thogh þat hir housbond pꝰersent were or non

And Iugement of so grete euquite
Þat she fro heuen as men wende
Peple to saue and euꝰery wrong to amende
Noght long tyme aftꝰer þis Griseld
Was wedded she a doghter haþ Ibore
Alle hadd she leuer han been a knaue child
Glad was þe marquys ⁊ his folke þerfore
For þogh a mayden child come alle by fore
She may to a knaue child atteyne
By liklyhed sithene she is not bareyne
Therfore as it falliþ tymes mo
Whan þis child hath souked but a þrow
This marquys in his hert longeth so
To tempte his wif hir sadnes to know
Þat he ne myght fro his hert þrow
This merueilous desire his wif to assay

He hadde assaied hir Inogh by fore
And fond hir euꝰer god wat nedith it

Þogh some men preise it for a sotel witte
But as for me I say þat euyl it sitte
To assaie a wif whan it is no nede
And putten hir in Anguys and in drede
For wiche þis marquys wroght in þis manꝰere
He can a nyght allone þer as she lay
With sterne face and trouble chere
And said tho Griseld quod he þat day
Þat I ȝow toke out of ȝoure pore array
And put ȝow in estate of hyh noblesse
Ȝe han not ȝet for ȝeten as I gesse
¶ I seye Griseld þis pꝰersent dignite
In wiche I haue putte ȝow as I trowe
Maketh ȝow noght forȝitful for to be
Þat I ȝow toke in pouer estate fullowe
For eny þing ȝe motte ȝoure seluen knowe
Take hede of euꝰery word þat I ȝow say
Þer is no wight þat herith þis but we twei
¶ Ȝe wotte ȝoure self wel . how þat ȝe come here
In to þis hous it is not long a go
And þoghe to me ȝe ben leue and dere
Vnto my gentiles ȝe ben no þing so
The sei to hem it is grete shame ⁊ wo
For to ben suget and in seruage
To þe þat art borne of so low lynage
¶ And namely sithyn þi doghter was bore
Þese wordes han þei spoke douteles
But I desire as I haue don here byfore
To lyue my lif with hem in rest ⁊ pees
I may not in þis cas ben recheles
I most done with þi doghter for þe beste
Nat as I wold but as my genteles les
¶ And ȝit god woot þis is wel loth to me
But natheles with oute ȝoure writyng
I wole not do but þis I wil quod he
That ȝe to me assent as in þis thing
Schewith now ȝoure pacience in ȝor worching
That ȝe me by hight and swore in ȝor vilage
Þat day þat maked was oure mariage
What she had herd al þis she was not amevid
Neiþꝰer in word or in chere or in Contynance
For as it Semed she was not a greued
She said lord alle lyth in ȝoure plesance

Ben ȝoures alle and ȝe may saue or spille
Ȝoure owne þing wether þat ȝe wille
Þer may no þing so god my soule saue
Likyng to ȝow þat may displese me
Ne I desire no thing to haue
Ne dred to lese saue only ȝe
Þis wil is myn hert ⁊ ay shal be
No lengeþ of tyme or deþ may his deface
Neþer change my corage into oþer place
Glad was þe marquys for hir vnswaryng
But ȝit he feynet as he were not so
Alle drery was his chere and his lokyng
When she shuld out of þe Chambre go
Sone aftir þis a forlong wey or two
He pleynly haþ told al his entente
Vnto a man wiche to his wif he sente
A maner seriant was þis pꝰeruy man
Þe wiche þat feithful ofte I fond he had
In þinges grete and eke suche folke wel can
Don execucions of þinges bad

And when þis sergeant wist his lordes wille
Into þe chambre he stalked hym wel stille
¶ Madame he said ȝe mot forȝeue it me
Þogh I do þing to wiche I am constreyned
Ȝe ben so wyse þat wel knowen ȝe
Þat lordes hestes may not ben feyned
Þei mowne wel ben wailed or cōmpleyned
But men most nede vnto her leste Obeie
And so wol I ther is no more to seie
¶ That child I am comaunded to take
And spake nomore but þe child he hent

As he wold han slayn hym er he went
Grisild mote alle suffre ⁊ alle consente

Suspecte þe tyme þat he bygan
For hir doghter þat she loued so

But nettheles she neither wept ne siked
Confermyng hir to þat marquys liked
¶ And atte þe laste speke she bygan
And mekely to þe sergeant praide
So as he was a . worthi gentil man
Þat she most kisse hir child er þat hit deide
And in hir barme þis litul child she leide

¶ And þus she said in hir benigne vois
Fare wel my child I shal þe neuꝰer se
But sithen I haue marked þe withe þe croys

Thi soule litul child I hym be take
For þis nyght dyen shalt þou for my sake
I trow þat to a norice in þis cas
Hit had ben hard þis rewith for to se
Wel myght a moder þan cry alas
But natheles so sad stidfast was she
Þat she endured alle aduꝰersite
And to þe sergeant mekely she saide
Haue here a ȝayn my litel ȝong maide
¶ And goth now quod she and doth my lordes hest
And oo þing wold I pray of ȝoure grace
Þat but my lord for bede ȝow atte leste
Burieth þis litul body in some place
Þat no bestes ne briddes it to rase
But he no word to þe purpos wole sey
But toke þe child and went vpon his way
¶ This sergeant come to þe lord a gayn
And of Griseldes wordes and of hir chere
He told hym poynt fro poynt in short and playn
And hym pꝰersentid with his doghter dere
Somwhat þis lord hade rewhthe in his manꝰere
But naþeles his purpos held he stille

And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe

Þat no man shold know of his entent
Ne whennes he come ne whider he went
But at Boloyne to his suster dere
Þat þo of pavie was countesse
He shold hir take and shewe hir þis matere
Bysechyng her to done hir bysynes
This child to fostre in alle gladesse
And whos child þat hit was he bade hir hide
From euery wight for oght þat myght bitide
This sergeant goth and hath fulfillid þis þing
But to þis marquys now retorne we
For now goth he wel oft ymagynyng
Ȝif by his wif he myght see
And by hir wordes pꝰerceyue þat she
Were choynged but he cowde neuꝰer fynde

And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym on euꝰery manꝰer wise
Ne of hir doghter a . word spake she
None accident for none aduersite

Nempnet she for ȝernest ne for game
N þis estate passed ben foure ȝere
Er she with child was but as god wold
A . knaue child she bare by þis walter
Wel gracious and faire to be hold
And when folke hit to his fader told
Noght only he but alle þe Contre merie
Was for þis child ⁊ god þei þank ⁊ herie

This marquys caght ȝit anoþꝰer lest
To tempten his wif ȝit aftꝰer ȝif he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men knowen noon mesure
When þei fynden a pacient creature
Wif quod þis marquys ȝe haue hed er þis
My peple sekely berith oure mariage
And namely sithen my son borne is
Now it is wers þat euer in oure Age
The murmr sleeþ myn hert ⁊ myn corage
For to myne Eres comeþ þe vois so smert
Þat it wel nygh distroieþ at myn hert
Now say men þus whan walter is gon
Þan shal þe blode of Ianycle succede
And ben oure lord for other haue we non
Suche wordes sayn my peple it is no drede
Wel aught I of suche murmorur take hede
For certenly I drede suche sentence
Þagh þei noght pleynly speke in myn audience
I wold lyue in pees if þat I myght
Wherfore I am disposed viterly
As I his suster serued by nyght
Right I thenke to serue hym priyly
Þus warne I ȝow þat ȝe not sodenly
Out of ȝoure self for no wo shuld outraie

I haue quod she saide and euꝰer shal
I wol desire no þing certayn
But as ȝow lust not greueth me at alle
Þogh þat my doghter and my son be slayn

I haue had no part of children tweyne
But first seknes and aftꝰer wo ⁊ peyne
Ȝe beth oure lord doth with ȝoure owne þing
Right as ȝow lust and asketh no rede of me
For as I lefte at home alle my clothing
When I ferst come to right so quod she

Ȝe for an hier clout to wrap me

But sires to ȝow it is no curtesie

Ȝe shuld arise þerfore I ȝeue ȝow rede

Now sires ȝif it be to ȝow so leef

Ne for ȝoure bost he nyl hym no thing hide

Þat doūn þei sette hem by þe pꝰercious hord

My witte is grete þogh I bourd ⁊ pley
This tresour hath fortune to vs ȝeuen

Ey pꝰercious goddes hert who wend
To Day þat we shuld haue so faire a grace

For wel I wot þat alle þis gold is oures
Thenne were we in high felicite
But trewly by day it may not be
Men wold sayn þat we were thefes strong
And for oure owne tresour doūn vs hong
As wisely and as slegly as it myght
This tresour most I caried be by nyght
Wherfor I rede lete loke a monges alle
To draw and lete se where þe cutte wil falle
He þat hath þe cut with hert blithe
Shalle renne to towne ⁊ þat ful swithe

And two of vs shul kepen ful subtilly

When it is nyght we wil þis tresour carie

Þat oon of hem broght gras in his fest

And forth toward þe tou he went anon
And also sone as he was gone
Þat oon of hem spake þus vnto þat other
Þow wost wel þou art myn owne sworne brother
Þi ꝓprofite wil I telle þe a noon
Þou wost wel þat oure felow is gon
And here is gold and þat right grete plente
Þat it shal departid be a mong vs thre

Þat is departid were a mong vs to
Had I not don a frendes turne to the
Þat other vnswared I not how þat myght be

What shold we do þat it myght be so
Shal it be Conseil saide þe first shrewe
And I shal tellen in wordes fewe
What we shul doon ⁊ bryng it a boute
I grant quod the other oute of doute
Þat be my trouthe I wol not the be wreyen

Loke whan he is sette and þat a noon

Whiles þat þou strogelist wtith hym as in game

And þan shal alle þis gold departed be
My dere frend by twix the and me
Þan may we both oure lustes fulfille
And pleie at þe dise right at oure owne wille
And thise accorded ben þise shrewes twei
To sle þe þrid as ȝe herd me say
This ȝongest wiche þat went to þe toūn
Ful oft in his hert it rolled vp and dou
Þe beaute of thise floreyn faire and bright
O lord quod he if it were so þat I myght

Ther nys no man þat lyuyth vndir trone
Of gold þat shuld lyue as mery as I
And at þe last þe feend oure enmy
Put in his þoght þat he shuld poyson boye
With wiche he myght sleen his felawes tweie
For whi þe fend fond hym in suche lyuyng

For þis was vtterly his entent
To sleen hem both ⁊ neuꝰer to repente
And forth he goth no lengꝰer wold he tarie

And saide he wold wreke hym if he myght

Þe potikarie vnswarid þou shalt haue

In alle þis world þer nys no creature
