¶ Here bigynneth the Shipmannes tale
A Marchant whilom / dwelled at Seint Denys
That riche was / for which men helde hym wys
A wyf he hadde / of excellent beautee
And compaignable / and reuelous was she
Which is a thyng that causeth moore dispence
Than worth / is al the cheere and reuerence
That men hem doon / at festes and at daunces
Swiche salutacions / and contenances
Passen / as dooth a shadwe vp on the wal
But wo is hym / that payen moot for al
The sely housbonde / algate he moot paye
He moot vs clothe / and he moot vs arraye
Al for his owene worship / richely
In which array / we dauncen iolily
And if þtat he noght may / ꝑperauenture
Or ellis / list no swich dispense endure
But thynketh / it is wasted and ylost
Thanne moot another / payen for oure cost
Or lene vs gold / and that is ꝑperilous
This noble Marchant heeld a worthy hous
ffor which / he hadde alday / so greet repair
ffor his largesse / and for his wyf was fair
That wonder is / but herkneth to my tale
Amonges alle hise gestes / grete and smale
¶ Ther was a Monk a fair man and a bold
I trowe / a thritty wynter / he was old
That euere in oon / was drawyng to that place
This yonge Monk that was so fair of face
Aqueynted was so / with the goode man
Sith that hir firste knewliche bigan
That in his hous / as famulier was he
As it is possible / any freend to be
And for as muchel / as this goode man
And eek this Monk / of which þtat I bigan
Were bothe two yborn / in o village
The Monk hym claymeth / as for cosynage
And he agayn / he seith nat ones nay
But was as glad ther of / as fowel of day
For to his herte / it was a gret plesance
Thus been they knyt with eterne alliance
And ech of hem / gan oother for tassure
Of bretherhede / whil þtat hir lyf may dure
¶ ffree was daun Iohn / and manly of dispence
As in that hous / and ful of diligence
To doon plesance / and also greet costage
He nat forgat to yeue the leeste page
In al that hous / but after hir degree
He yaf the lord / and sith al his meynee
Whan þtat he cam / som manere honeste thyng
For which / they were as glad of his comyng
As fowel is fayn / whan þtat the sonne vp riseth
Namoore of this as now / for it suffiseth
¶ But so bifel / this Marchant on a day
Shoop hym / to make redy his array
Toward the town of Brugges / for to fare
To byen there / a porcion of ware
For which he hath / to Parys sent anon
A messager / and preyed hath daun Iohn
That he sholde come / to Seint Denys and pleye
With hym / and with his wyf a day or tweye
Er he to Brugges wente / in alle wise
¶ This noble Monk of which I yow deuyse
Hath of his Abbot as hym list licence
By cause he was a man / of heigh prudence
And eek an Officer / out for to ryde
To seen hir granges / and hir bernes wyde
And vn to Seint Denys / he comth anon
Who was so welcome / as my lord Daun Iohn
Oure deere cosyn / ful of curteisye
With hym broghte he / a Iubbe of Maluesye
And eek another ful of fyn vernage
And volatil / as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem / ete and drynke and pleye
This Marchant and this Monk / a day or tweye
¶ The thridde day / this Marchant vp ariseth
And on his nedes / sadly hym auyseth
And vp / into his Countour hous goth he
To rekene with hym self / wel may be
Of thilke yeer / how þtat it with hym stood
And how þtat he / despended hadde his good
And if that he / encressed were or noon
Hise bokes / and his bagges / many oon
He leyth biforn hym / on his Countyng bord
Ful riche was his tresor / and his hord
For which ful faste / his Countour dore he shette
And eek he nolde / þtat no man sholde hym lette
Of his acountes / for the mene tyme
And thus he sit / til it was passed pirime
¶ Daun Iohn was risen / in the morwe also
And in the gardyns / walketh to and fro
And hath his thynges seyd / ful curteisly
¶ This goode wyf / cam walkyng piriuely
In to the gardyn / ther he walketh softe
And hym salueth / as she hath doon ofte
A mayde child / cam in hir compaignye
Which as hir list she may gouerne and gye
For yet vnder the yerde was the mayde
¶ O deere cosyn myn / Daun Iohn she sayde
What eyleth yow / so rathe for to ryse
¶ Nece quod he / it oghte ynow suffise
Fyue houres / for to slepe / vp on a nyght
But it were / for an old apalled wight
As been this wedded men / þtat lye and dare
As in a forme / sit a wery hare
Were al forstraught wtith houndes grete ⁊ smale
But deere Nece / why be ye so pale
I trowe cꝰertes / that oure goode man
Hath yow laboured / sith the nyght bigan
That yow were nede / to resten hastily
And with that word / he lough ful myrily
And of his owene thoght he weex al reed
¶ This faire wyf / gan for to shake hir heed
And seyde thus / ye god woot al quod she
Nay cosyn myn / it stant nat so with me
For by that god / that yaf me soule and lyf
In al the Reawme of ffrance / is ther no wyf
That lasse lust hath / to that sory pley
For I may synge / allas and weilawey
That I was born / but to no wight quod she
Dar I nat telle / how þtat it stant with me
Wher fore I thynke / out of this land to wende
Or ellis / of my self / to make an ende
So ful am I / of drede / and eek of care
¶ This Monk bigan / vp on this wyf to stare
And seyde / allas / my Nece god forbede
That ye / for any sorwe / or any drede
Fordo your self / but telleth me your grief
ꝐPer auenture / I may in youre meschief
Conseille / or helpe / and therfore telleth me
Al youre anoy / for it shal been secree
For on my Porthors / I make an oth
That neuꝰere in my lif / for lief / or loth
Ne shal I / of no conseil / yow biwreye
¶ The same agayn to yow / quod she I seye
By god / and by this Porthors / I swere
Thogh men me wolde / al in to peces tere
Ne shal I neuꝰere / for to gon to helle
Biwreye a word / of thyng þtat ye me telle
Nat for no cosynage / ne alliance
But verraily / for loue and affiance
Thus been they sworn / and her vp on they keste
And ech of hem / tolde oother what hem leste
¶ Cosyn quod she / if þtat I hadde a space
As I haue noon / and namely in this place
Thanne wolde I telle / a legende of my lyf
What I haue suffred / sith I was a wyf
With myn housbonde / al be he youre cosyn
¶ Nay quod this Monk by god and Seint Martin
He is namore / cosyn vn to me
Than is this leef þtat hangeth on the tree
I clepe hym so / by Seint Denys of ffrance
To han / the moore cause of aqueyntance
Of yow / which I haue loued specially
Abouen alle wommen / sikerly
This swere I yow / on my ꝓprofessioūn
Telleth youre grief / lest þtat he come adoun
And hasteth yow / and goth awey anon
¶ My deere loue quod she / o my Daun Iohn
Ful lief were me / this conseil for to hyde
But out it moot I may namoore abyde
¶ Myn housbonde is to me / the worste man
That euere was / sith þtat the world bigan
But sith I am a wyf / it sit nat me
To tellen no wight of oure piriuetee
Neither abedde / ne in noon oother place
God shilde / I sholde it tellen for his garace
A wyf ne shal nat seyn / of hir housbonde
But al honour / as I kan vnderstonde
Saue vn to yow / thus muche I tellen shal
As help me god / he is noght worth at al
In no degree / the value of a flye
But yet me greueth moost his nygardye
And wel ye woot þtat wommen naturelly
Desiren thynges .vj. as wel as I
They wolde / þtat hir housbondes sholde be
¶ Hardy and wise / and riche / and ther to free
And buxom vn to his wyf / and fressh abedde
But by that ilke lord / that for vs bledde
For his honour / my self for to arraye
A Sonday next I moot nedes paye
An hundred frankes / or ellis am I lorn
Yet were me leuꝰere / þtat I were vnborn
Than me were doon / a sclaundre / or vileynye
And if myn housbonde eek / myghte it espye
I nere but lost and ther fore I yow preye
Lene me this sōmme / or ellis moot I deye
Daun Iohn I seye / lene me thise hundred frankes
Pardee / I wol noght faile yow my thankes
If þtat yow list to doon / that I yow praye
For at a cꝰerteyn day / I wol yow paye
And doon to yow / what plesance and seruyse
That I may doon / right as yow list deuyse
And but .I. do / god take on me vengeance
As foul / as euꝰere hadde Genelou of ffrance
¶ This gentil Monk answerde in this manere
Now trewely / myn owene lady deere
I haue quod he / on yow so gret a routhe
That I yow swere / and plighte yow my trouthe
That whan youre housbonde / is to fflandres fare
I wol deliuere yow / out of this care
For I wol brynge yow / an hundred frankes
And with that word / he caughte hir by the flankes
And hir embraceth harde / and kiste hir ofte
Goth now youre wey quod he / al stille and softe
And lat vs dyne / as soone / as þtat ye may
For by my chilyndre / it is Pryme of day
Goth now / and beth as trewe as I shal be
¶ Now ellis / god forbede sire quod she
And forth she goth / as iolif as a pye
And bad the Cokes / þtat they sholde hem hye
So þtat men myghte dyne / and that anon
Vp to hir housbonde / is his wyf ygon
And knokketh at his Countour boldely
¶ Who ys ther quod he / Peter it am I
Quod she / what sire / how longe wol ye faste
How longe tyme / wol ye rekene and caste
Youre sommes / and youre bokes / and youre thynges
The deuel haue part on alle swiche rekenynges
Ye haue ynogh pardee / of goddes sonde
Com doun to day / and lat youre bagges stonde
Ne be ye nat ashamed / that Daun Iohn
Shal fastynge / al this day elenge gon
What lat vs heere a masse / and go we dyne
¶ Wyf quod this man / litel kanstow deuyne
The curious bisynesse / that we haue
For of vs chapmen / also god me saue
And by that lord / that clepid is Seint Yue
Scarsly amonges .xij. x. shul thryue
Continuelly / lastyng vn to oure age
We may wel make cheere / and good visage
And dryue forth the world / as it may be
And kepen oure estat in pryuetee
Til we be dede / or ellis that we pleye
A pilgrymage / or goon out of the weye
And ther fore / haue I gret / necessitee
Vp on this queynte world / tauyse me
For euere mo / we mote stonde in drede
Of hap and ffortune / in oure chapmanhede
¶ To fflandres wol I go / tomorwe at day
And come agayn / as soone as euꝰere I may
For which my deere wyf / I thee biseke
As be to euery wight buxom and meke
And for to kepe oure good / be curious
And honestly / gouerne wel oure hous
Thow hast ynow / in euery maner wise
That to a thrifty houshold / may suffise
Thee lakketh noon array / ne no vitaille
Of siluer in thy purs / shaltow nat faille
And with that word / his Countour dore he shette
And doun he goth / no lenger wolde he lette
But hastily / a masse was ther seyd
And spedily / the tables were yleyd
And to the dyner / faste they hem spedde
And richely this Monk the chapman fedde
¶ At after dyner / daun Iohn sobrely
This chapman took a part and piriuely
He seyde hym thus / cosyn it standeth so
That wel I se / to Brugges wol ye go
God and Seint Austyn / spede yow and gyde
I pray yow cosyn / wysly þtat ye ryde
Gouerneth yow also / of youre diete
Atemprely / and namely / in this hete
Bitwix vs two / nedeth no strange fare
Farewel cosyn / god shilde yow fro care
And if þtat any thyng by day or nyght
If it lye in my power and my myght
That ye me wol comande / in any wise
It shal be doon / right as ye wol deuyse
¶ O thyng er þtat ye goon / if it may be
I wold preye yow / for to lene me
An hundred frankes / for a wyke or tweye
For cꝰerteyn bestes / þtat I moste beye
To store with a place / that is oures
God help me so / I wolde it were youres
I shal nat faille / seurely of my day
Nat for a thousand frankes / a myle way
But lat this thyng be secree / I yow preye
For yet to nyght thise bestes moot I beye
And fare now wel / myn owene cosyn deere
Grant mꝰercy / of youre cost and of youre cheere
¶ This noble Marchant gentilly anon
Answerde and seyde / o cosyn myn daun Iohn
Now sikerly / this is a smal requeste
My gold is youres / whan þtat it yow leste
And nat oonly my gold / but my chaffare
Tak what yow list god shilde þtat ye spare
But o thyng is / ye knowe it wel ynow
Of Chapmen / that hir moneye is hir plow
We may creance / whil we han a name
But goldlees for to been / it is no game
Pay it agayn / whan it lyth in youre ese
After my myght ful fayn wol I yow plese
¶ Thise hundred frankes / he fette forth anon
And piriuely / he took hem to Daun Iohn
No wight in al this world / wiste of this lone
Sauyng this Marchant and daun Iohn allone
They drynke / and speke / and rome a while ⁊ pleye
Til that Daun Iohn / rideth to his Abbeye
¶ The morwe cam / and forth this Marchant rydeth
To fflandres ward / his Prentys wel hym gydeth
Til he cam / in to Brugges murily
Now goth this Marchant faste and bisily
Aboute his nede / and byeth and creaūnceth
He neither / pleyeth at the dees / ne daunceth
But as a Marchant shortly for to telle
He let his lyf / and ther I lete hym dwelle
¶ The sonday next / the Marchant was agon
To Seint Denys / ycomen is Daun Iohn
With crowne and berd / al fressh ⁊ newe shaue
In al the hous / ther nas so litel a knaue
Ne no wight ellis / þtat he nas ful fayn
That my lord Daun Iohn / was come agayn
And shortly / to the poynt right for to gon
This faire wyf acorded with Daun Iohn
That for thise hundred frankes / he sholde al nyght
Haue hire in his armes / bolt vpright
And this acord / ꝑperfourned was in dede
In myrthe al nyght a bisy lyf they lede
Til it was day / that daun Iohn wente his way
And bad the meynee / fare wel haue good day
For noon of hem / ne no wight in the town
Hath of Daun Iohn / right no suspecioun
And forth he rydeth hom / til his Abbeye
Or where hym list namoore of hym I seye
¶ This Marchant whan þtat ended was the faire
To Seint Denys / he gan for to repaire
And with his wyf / he maketh feste and cheere
And telleth hir / that chaffare is so deere
That nedes / moste he make a cheuyssance
For he was bounden / in a reconyssance
To paye / twenty thousand sheeld anon
For which / this Marchant is to Parys gon
To borwe / of cꝰerteyne freendes / that he hadde
A cꝰerteyn frankes / and sōmme wtith hym he ladde
And whan þtat he was come / in to the town
For greet chiertee / and greet affeccioun
Vn to Daun Iohn / he first goth / hym to pleye
Nat for to axe / or borwe of hym moneye
But for to wite / and seen of his welfare
And for to tellen hym / of his chaffare
As freendes doon / whan they been met yfeere
Daun Iohn / hym maketh feste / and murye cheere
And he hym tolde agayn / ful specially
How he hadde / wel yboght and garaciously
Thanked be god / al hool his marchandise
Saue þtat he moste / in alle maner wyse
Maken a cheuyssance / as for his beste
And thanne / he sholde been / in ioye and reste
¶ Daun Iohn answerde / certes I am fayn
That ye in heele / ar comen hom agayn
And if þtat I were riche / as haue I blisse
Of twenty thousand sheeld / sholde ye nat mysse
For ye so kyndely / this oother day
Lente me gold / and as I kan and may
I thanke yow / by god / and by Seint Iame
But nathelees / I took vn to oure dame
Yowre wyf at hom / the same gold agayn
Vp on youre bench / she woot it wel certayn
By cꝰerteyn toknes / that I kan yow telle
Now by youre leue / I may no lenger dwelle
Oure Abbot wol out of this town anon
And in his compaignye / moot I gon
Greet wel oure dame / myn owene Nece swete
And fare wel deere cosyn / til we meete
¶ This Marchant which þtat was ful war and wys
Creanced hath / and payed eek in Parys
To cꝰerteyn lombardes / redy in hir hond
The somme of gold / and gat of hem his bond
And hoom he gooth / murye as a Papyniay
For wel he knew / he stood in swich array
That nedes moste he wynne / in that viage
A thousand frankes / abouen al his costage
¶ His wyf ful redy / mette hym at the gate
As she was wont of old vsage algate
And al that nyght in myrthe they bisette
For he was riche / and cleerly out of dette
¶ Whan it was day / this Marchant gan embrace
His wyf al newe / and kiste hir on hir face
And vp he goth / and maketh it ful tough
Namoore quod she / by god ye haue ynough
And wantownely agayn / with hym she pleyde
Til at the laste / this Marchant seyde
¶ By god quod he / I am alitel wroth
With yow my wyf / al thogh it be me looth
And woot ye why / by god as þtat I gesse
That ye han maad / a manere strangenesse
Bitwixen me / and my cosyn Daun Iohn
Ye sholde han warned me / er I had gon
That he yow hadde / a hundred frankes payed
By redy tokne / and heeld hym yuele apayed
For that I to hym / spak of cheuyssance
Me semed so / as by his conte
But nathelees / by god oure heuene kyng
I thoghte nat to axe of hym no thyng
I pray thee wyf ne do namoore so
Tel me alwey / er that I fro thee go
If any dettour / hath in myn absence
Ypayed thee / lest thurgh thy necligence
I myghte hym axe / a thyng þtat he hath payed
¶ This wyf / was nat afered ne afrayed
But boldely she seyde / and that anon
Marie I diffye / the false Monk daun Iohn
I kepe nat of his toknes / neuꝰer a del
He took me cꝰerteyn gold / this woot I wel
What yuel thedam / on his Monkes snowte
For god it woot I wende with outen dowte
That he hadde yeue it me / by cause of yow
To doon ther with / myn honour / and my prow
For cosynage / and eek for bele cheere
That he hath had / ful ofte tymes heere
¶ But sith I se / it stant in this disioynt
I wole answere yow / shortly to the poynt
Ye han mo slakker dettours / than am I
For I wol paye yow / wel and redily
Fro day to day / and if so be I fayle
I am youre wyf / score it vp on my tayle
And I shal paye / as soone as euere I may
For by my trouthe / I haue on myn array
And nat in wast bistowed euꝰery del
And for I haue / bistowed it so wel
For youre honour for goddes sake I seye
As be nat wrooth / but lat vs laughe ⁊ pleye
Ye shal / my ioly body han to wedde
By god / I wol noght paye yow but abedde
Forgyue it me / myn owene spouse deere
Turn hiderward / and maketh bettre cheere
¶ This Marchant saugh / ther was no remedye
And for to chide / it nere but folye
Syn that the thyng may nat amended be
Now wyf he seyde / and I foryeue it thee
But by thy lyf ne be namoore so large
Keep bet thy good / this yeue I thee in charge
Thus endeth my tale / and god vs sende
Taillynge ynough / vn to oure lyues ende
¶ Here endeth / the Shipmannes tale

To Sette a man þat is fulfilled of vice
In highe degre and Emꝑperoure hym calle
By god out of his Sete I wole hym trise
When he lest wenyth Sonnest shal he falle
The peple ros vpon hym on a nyght
For his defaute and when he it aspied
Oute of his dores a none he hath hym dighte
Alone and þer he wened haue ben alyed
He knokked fast and ay þe more he cried
Þe Faster Shetten þay þe dores alle
Tho wist he welle he hadd hym Self mysgied
And went his way no lengꝰer dorst he calle
The peple cried and rombled vp ⁊ done
Þat with hes heres herd he how he saide
Where is þis fals traitour this Neroune
For fere almost out of his witte a braide
And to his goddes pitously he saide
For socour but it myght not by tide
For drede of þis hym þoght þat he diede
And ranne in to a gardyn hym to hide
And in this gardyn fond he Chirles twei
Þat Seten by a fuyre grete ⁊ rede
And to þe Cherles twei he can to preie
To Slen hym and gurden of his hede
Þat to his body when þat he were dede
Were none dispite I done for his diffame
Hym Self he Slogh he coud no bettꝰer rede
Of wiche fortune lowh ⁊ made a game
Was neuer Captayn vnder a kyng
Þat regnes mo put in subieccion
Ne strenger was in feld of alle þing
As in his tyme nor grettꝰer of renoūn
Ne more pompous in highe pꝰersūnpcion
Þan Olypherne wiche fortune ay kest
So lykerouly and lad hym vp ⁊ done
Til þat his hed was of er þat he wiste
Noght only þat þis world hade of hym awe
For lesyng of Richesse and of liberte
But he made euꝰery man reney his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lord saide he
Non other god shuld honoured be
A ȝenst his hest no wight dar trespace
Sauf in Bethulia a strong Cite
Where Eliachim a prest was of þat place
But take kepe of þe deth of olyferne
A myd his Ost he dronke lay a nyght
WIth inne his tente large as is a berne
And ȝit for alle his pompe ⁊ alle his myght
Iudith a wōmman as he lay vpright
Slepyng his hode of smote ⁊ fro his tente
Ful piriuely sche stale fro euꝰery wight
What nedith it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his high ⁊ l rial magiste
His hiȝe pride his werke renymous
For suche annother was neuꝰer none as he
Redith wiche þat he was in Machabe
And redithe þe proude wordes þat he saide
And whi he felle fro his ꝓprosꝑperite
And in an hulle how wrechidly he deide
Fortune hadd hym haunced so in pride
Þat veraily he wend he myght a teyne
Vnto þe sterres vp euꝰery side
And in a balance p to weie þe monteyne
And alle þe flodes of þe see restreyne
And goddes peple hadde he moste in hate
Hem wold he sle in torment ⁊ peyne
Wenyng þa god ne myght his piride abate
And for þat Nychamour and thymothe
With Iewes were venquysshed myghtily
Vnto þe Iewes suche an hate had he
Þat he hade greither his chare ful hastily
And swore and saide ful despitously
Vnto Ierlm he wold eft sone
To wreke his Ire on hit ful cruely
But of his purpos he was let ful sone
God of his manace hym ful sore smote
With inuisible wond ay vncurable
Þat in his guttes karf so and bote
That his peynes were inportable
And certoynly þe wreche was resonable
For mony mannes guttes did he payn
But fro his purpos cursed and dampnable
For alle his smert he nold hym noght restreyne
But bade anone apparailen his Oste
And sodeynly er he was of hit warre
God daunted alle his pride ⁊ alle his boste
For he so Sore felle out of his chare
Þat hurte his lymes ⁊ his skyn to tare
So þat he ne myght goo ne ride
But in a chaire men a boute hym bare
And for brused both bak ⁊ side
che of god him smote so cruely
body wicked wermes crepte
with alle he stanke so oribely
of alle his meagne þtat hym kepte
he woke or elles Slepte
noght þe stynke of hym endure
In myschief he wailed and eke wepte
And knew god lord of euꝰery creature
To alle his ost and to hym Self also
Ful wlatsome was þe stynke of his Careyne
No man myght hym bere to ne fro
And in his stynke and in his orible peyne
He Starf ful wrechidly in a monteyne
Þus hath þis Robbour and þis homicide
Þat many man made to wepe ⁊ pleyne
Suche guerdon as by longith vnto pride
The storie of Alisaundre is so comune
Þat euꝰery wight þat hath discrecion
Hath herd som what or alle of his fortune
Þis wide world as in conclusion
He wan by strenghe or for his hyȝ renou
Þei were glad for pees vnto hym sende
Þe pride of man and beste he laide a done
Wer so he came vnto þe worldes ende
Comꝑperison myȝt neuꝰer be maked
By twix hym and an other conquerour
For alle þis world for drede of hym . hath quaked
He was of knyghthode and of fredom floure
Fortune hy made þe heier of hir honour
Saf wyn and wōmmen no þing myght a swage
His hyȝe entent in Armes and laboure
So was he ful of louyng Corage
What pite were hit to hym þeih I ȝow told
Of darius and an hundred þousand moo
Of kynges prynces Erles bold
Wiche he conquered and broght hem in to wo
I say as fer as man may ride or go
Þe world was his what shold I more devise
For þogh I write and told ȝow euꝰermoo
Of his knyȝthod it myght not suffice
Twelue ȝere he regned as saith machabe
Philippe sone of macidone he was
Þat firste was kyng of grece þe contre
O worthi gentel Alisaundre Alas
Þat euꝰer shuld falle suche a caas
Enpoysoned of þyn folke þu were
Thy s fortune hath turnes in to an aas
And ȝit for the ne wepe sche neuꝰer a tere
Who shal ȝeue men teres to compleyne
Þe deth of gentelnesse and of fraunchise
Þat alle þe world weldenꝰer in his demeyne
And ȝit hym þoght it myght not suffice
So ful was his Corage of highe Enpirise
Alas who shal me helpe to endite
Fals fortune ⁊ poison to dispise
Þe wiche two of alle þis wo I wite
By wisdom manhed and by labour
Fro humblehed ⁊ fro Roial magiste
Vp roos he Iulius þe conquerour
Þat alle þe occident by land ⁊ se
By strenght of hand or elles of trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarie
And Sithens of Rome þe Emꝑperour was he
Til þat fortune wax his aduꝰersarie
O myght Cesar þat in Tessalie
A ȝenst pompeus fader þyn in lawe
That of Orient had alle þe Chiualrie
As fer as þat þe day bygynnyth to dawe
Þeigh þurgh þyn knyghthode hast hem take ⁊ Slawe
Sauf few folke þat with pompeus fledde
Þurgh wiche þou puttest alle þe orient in awe
Thanke fortune þat so wel þe spedde
But now a litel . while I wole be waile
This pompeus þis noble gouernour
Of Rome wiche þat fleigh at þis bataile
I Say oon of his men a fals traitour
His hedde of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and hym þe hede broght
Alas pompeie of þe Orient conqueroure
Þat fortune vnto suche a funt broght
To Rome aȝain repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe laureate ful hiȝe
But on a tyme brutus Cassius
Þat euꝰer hadde of his estate envie
Ful pꝰeruyly hade made conspiricie
A ȝenst þis Iulius in subtille wise
And cast þe place in wiche he shuld die
With boydkyns as I shal ȝow devise
This Iulius to þe Capithole went
Vpon a day as he was wont to gone
And in þe Capithole a non hym hent
Þis false brutus and his foule foon
And styked hym with boydekyns anone
With mony a wound ⁊ þus þei lete hym lie
But neuꝰer gront he at noo stroke sauf one
Or elles at st two but if his storie lie
So manly was þis Iulius of hert
And so wel loued estately honeste
Þat þogh his dedely wondes so Sore smerte
His mantel ouꝰer his hipes cast he
For no man shuld See his piriuyte
And as he lay on deinge in traunce
And wist verraily þat ded was he
Of honeste ȝit hadde he remembrance
Lucane to þis storie I recomende
And sweton and to vallerius Also
Þat of þis storie writeþ word ⁊ ende
How þat þise grete conquerous two
Fortune was firste frend ⁊ sithen a foo
No man ne truste vpon his fauour long
But haue hir in a waite for euꝰermo
Witnes on alle þise conquerous stronge
This Riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde
Of wiche Cresus Cyquus sore him dradde
Ȝit was he caught amyddes alle his pride
And to be brent men to þe fuyre hym ledde
But suche a reyne don from þe welkyn shadde
Þat Slowhe þe fuyre ⁊ made hym to eschape
But to be warre ȝit no grace he hadde
Til fortune on þe galewes made hym gape
Whe he Escaped was he con not stynte
For to by gynne a new reyn a ȝeyne
He wend wel for þat fortune hym Sent
Suche happe þat he Escaped þurgh þe reyne
Þat of his foos he myght not be Slayne
And Suche a sweuen vpon a nyght he mette
Of wiche he was so proude and eke fayne
Þat in vengeance he alle his hert sette
Vpon a tre he was as þat hym þoght
Þer Iubitꝰer hym wesshe both hals ⁊ side
And phebus eke a faire towail hym broght
To dry hym with and therfor wax his pride
And to his doughter þat stode hym by side
Wiche þat he knew in hyghe Sentence habonde
He bade hir telle hym what it signified
And she his dremes by gan right þus expone
The tre quod she þe galowes is to mene
And Iubiter bytokeneþ snow ⁊ reyne
And phebus with his towaile so clene
Tho ben þe sonne stremes for to sayne
Þu shalt a hanged be fadir cꝰertayne
Reyne shal þe wasche and Sonne Shal þe drie
Þus warned She hym ful plate ⁊ ful playne
His doughtꝰer that called was phanie
An honged was Cresus þe proude kyng
His roial trone myght hym not a vaile
Tregedie is none other man thing
Ne can in synnyng crie ne be waile
But þat fortune alway wole Assaile
With vnwar stroke þe regnes þat ben proude
For when men trusteþ hir þan wole she faile
And kouꝰer hir bright face with a cloude
Here endithe þe monkes

l.hi: Þe prologe of þe Nonne preost

div.l: HO quod the knyght gode sir no more of þis
Þat ȝe haue saide is right I nowh I wys
And mochel more for litel heuynes
Is right I now to mochel folke as I gesse
I sei for me it is a grete dishese
Wher þat men han ben in grete welth ⁊ ese
To heren of her sodeyn falle alas
And þe contrarie is Ioy ⁊ grete solas
As when a man hathe ben in pouer estate
And clymbith vp and waxith fortunate
And þere abidith in ꝓprosꝑperite
Suche þing is gladsome as it þinkith me
And þogh suche þing were godely for to telle
Ȝe quod oure Ost by seynt poules belle
Ȝe say right welle þis monke he clappeþ loude
He spake how fortune couꝰered in a cloude
I not neuꝰer what and also of tregedie
Righ no ȝe here and ꝑperde no remedie
It is for to be waile ne complayne
Þat þat is done and also it is a peyne
As ȝe han seide to here of heuynes
Sir monke nomore of þis so god ȝow blesse
Ȝoure tale annoyeth al þis companye
Suche talkyng is not worth a butterflie
I pray yow hertely telle vs sūnwhat elles
For syker ner þe clynkyng of ȝoure belles
Þat on ȝoure bridel hangith on euꝰery side
By heuyn kyng þat for vs alle deied
I shal for this falle done for to slepe
Al þogh þe slogh hadde neuꝰer ben so depe
Than hade ȝoure tale ben told in vayne
For certeynly as þise clerkes sayne
Where as a man may haue none audience
Noght helpith to tellen his sentence
And welle I wote þe substance is in me
Ȝif any thing shal wel reported be
Sir say sumwhat of huntyng I ȝow pray
Nay quod þe monke I haue no lust to play
Nou lethe a nothe telle as I haue told
Than spake oure Ost withe rude speche ⁊ bold
And saide vnto þe nonne preost anone
Come nere sir preost come hidir sir Iohan
Telle vs suche þinges as may oure hertes glade
Be mery þogh þow ride vpon a Iade
What þeigh þyn hors be foule ⁊ lene
If he wil serue þe rekke not a bene
Loke þat þyn hert be mery euꝰer moo
Ȝisse ost quod he so mote I ride or go
But I be meri I wisse I wille be blamed
And ryght a none he hath his tale a tamed
And þus he saide to vs euꝰerychon
Þis swete preest þis goode man sir Iohan
A pore widow somdel stope in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narow cotage
By sides a groue stondyng in a dale
This widow of wiche I told ȝow my tale
Sythens þilke day þat she was last a wif
In pacience ladde a ful symple lif
For litul was hir Catel ⁊ hir rent
By housbondry of suche as god hyr sent
She fand hir self and eke hir doughtren two
Thre large sowes hadde she ⁊ no mo
Thre kyn and eke a schepe þat hight malle
Ful soty was hir boure and eke hir halle
In wiche she ete mony a sclendre mele
Of poynant sause hir nedid neuꝰer a dele
No deynte morsel passed hir throte
Hir dyete was a cordant to hir Cote
Replecion made hir neuꝰer seke
A temꝑpere diete was alle hir phisik
And excercise and hert suffisaūnce
The goute letted hir no þing to daūnce
Ne poplexie shent not hir hede
No wyn dranke she neither white ne rede
Hir bord was ꝸserued most with white ⁊ blak
Milke and bron bred in wiche she fand no lake
Seyned bacon and sumtyme an eye or tweie
For she was as it were a manꝰer of a deie
A gardyn she had enclose all a boute
With stykes and a dry dyche wtithoute
In wiche she hadd a cok hight chanteclere
In alle þe land of crowyng was his pere
His vois was merier þen þe meri orgon
On masse daies þat in þe chirche gone
Wel siker was þe crowyng in his logge
Þei is a clokke or any abbay orlogge
By nature he knew eche assencion
Of equynoxial of thilke toūn
For when degres xv were discendid
Then knew he it myght not be amended
His combe was radder þan þe fyn Coral
And batailed as it were a Castel walle
I like azure were his legges ⁊ his toon
His belle was blake and as þe gette it shone
His nayles whiter þan þe lilie floure
And I like burnesshed gold was his colour
This gentil Cokke hadd in his gouꝰernance
Seuen hennes for to done his plesance
Wiche weren his sustres and his ꝑperamoures
And wondir I like to hym as of coloures
Of wiche þe fairest hewed vnder þrote
Was cleped faire damisel ꝑpertelote
Curteise she was dicrete and debonaire
And companable and bare hir self so faire
Sithyns þilke day she was vij nyght old
Þat trewly she hath the hert in hold
Of chaunteclere loken in euꝰery light
He loued hir so þat wel was hym þꝰerwith
But suche a Ioy as it was to here hem syng
When þat þe bright sonne gan to spryng
In swete a cord my lef is fare on lond
For þilk tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Bestes and briddes coude speke ⁊ syng
And so byfelle þat in þe dawenyng
As chaunteclere a mong his wyfes alle
Sate on his ꝑperche þat was in þe halle
And next hym satte þis faire ꝑpertelote
This chantecler gan gronen in his þrote
As a man þat is in his dreme dreched sore
And whan þat ꝑpertelote þus herd hym rore
She was a gast and saide hert dere
What eilith ȝow to grone in þis manere
Ȝe been a verrei sleper fy for shame
And he vnswared and said þus ma dame
I pray ȝow þat ȝe take it not a gref
By god me mette þat I was in meschief
Right now þat ȝit myn hert is sore a fright
Now god quod he my sweuen rede a right
And kepe my body out of þe foule pirisoūn
Me mette þat I romed vp ⁊ done
With Inne oure ȝerd where as I see a best
Was like an hond ⁊ wole haue made a rest
Vpon my body and wold haue hadd me deed
His colour was by twix white ⁊ rede
And typpit was his taile and bothe his Eres
With blak vnlike þe remenant of his heres
His snowte smale with glowyng eȝen tweie
Ȝit of his loke for fere almost I die
This Caused me my grownyng douteles
A voy quod she fy on ȝow herteles
Alas quod she for by þat god aboue
Now han ȝe lest myn hert ⁊ my loue
I con not loue a coward by my faithe
For certes what so eny wōmman saithe
We alle desiren if it myght be
To han housbondes hardi wise ⁊ fre
And secre ne no nyggard ne no fool
Ne hym þat is a gast of euꝰery tool
Ne none a vantoure by þat god aboue
How dorste ȝe sayne for shame vnto ȝoure loue
That any thing myght make ȝow a ferd
Haue ȝe nomannys hert ⁊ haue a berd
Alas and konne ȝe ben a gast of sweues
Sweues engendren of replexions
When humores ben to habundant in a wight
Certes þis dreme wiche ȝe han herd to nyght
Comythe of þe grete suꝑperfluite
Of ȝoure rede colour ꝑperde
Wiche causeth folke to dreme her dremes
Of arewes and of fuyres with rede lemes
Of rede bestes þat wolen hem bite
Of contek and of whelpes grete ⁊ lyte
Right as þe humore malycolie
Causith mony a man in slepe for to crie
For fere of beres and boles blake
Or elles blake deueles wolen hem take
Of other humores couthe I telle also
Þat wirken mony a man in slepe ful wo
But I wille passe as lightly as I can
Lo Caton wiche þat wasse so wise a man
Saide he not þus ne do no force of dremes
Now sir quod she when we fle fro þe bemes
For goddes loue takith sum laxatif
I conseil ȝow þe beste I wolle not lie
Þat bothe of coloure ⁊ malycolie
Ȝe purge ȝow and for ȝe shul not tarie
Thogh þat in þis toūn is none apoticarie
I shal my self to herbes techen ȝow
Þat shal be ȝoure hele and ȝoure prowe
And in þe gardyn two herbes shal I fynde
Þe wiche haue of her ꝓproperte by kynde
To purgen ȝou by nethe and eke a boue
For ȝetith noght þis for goddes owne loue
Ȝe ben ful colreke of complexion
Where þe sonne in his ascencion
Ne fynde ȝow replete of ȝoure humoures hote
And if it do I dar wel lay a grote
Þat ȝe shul haue a feuer tꝰercian
Or an agu þat may be ȝoure bane
A . day or two ȝe shul haue dygestyeus
Of wormes or ȝe take ȝoure laxatyues
Of laureal Centaure and of fumytere
Or elles of Ellebore þat growith þere
Of Catapuce or of gaytes buries
Of herbe yue growyn in oure ȝerd þꝰer merie is
Pek hem vpright as þei grow and ete hem In
Be mery housbond for ȝeure fadres kyne
Dredith no dreme I con say ȝoure nomore
Madame quod he gramꝰercy of ȝoure lore
But natheles as touching daun Caton
Þat hath of wisdom suche grete renou
By god men may in old bokes rede
On of þe grettest auctor out of drede
Of mony a man more of autorite
Then euꝰer Caton was so mote I the
Þat alle þe reuers sayn of þis sentence
And han wel founden by exꝑperience
Þat dremes ben significacions
As welle of Ioy as of tribulacions
Þat folke duren in þis pꝰersent lif pꝰersent
Þer nedith not to make of þis none argument
Þe verrai preef shewith it in dede
On of þe grettest autor out of drede
Saith þus þat whilom two felowes went
On pilgrymage in ful gode entent
And happed so þei comen into a thoūn
Where as þer was suche congregacion
Of peple and eke of straite herbygage
That þei fand as moche as a Cotage
In wiche þei bothe myght I logged be
Wherfore þei mosten of necessite
As for þat nyght departen of cōmpanye
And eche of hem goth in to his Ostelery
And toke his loggyng as it wold falle
Þat one of hem was logged in a stalle
Ferre in a ȝerd with oxen of þe ploghe
Þat other man was logged welle I noghe
As was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouerneth alle as in comme
And so byfelle long er it were day
Þis man mette in his bedd þer as he lay
How þat his felaw con on hym calle
And saide alas for in an oxe stalle
This nyght shal I be murdred þer I lye
Now helpe me dere brother or I die
In alle hast come to me he saide
This man oute of his slepe for fere a braide
But when þat he was wakened out of his slepe
He turned hym and toke of þis no kepe
Hym þoght his dreme was noght but a vanite
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed he
And atte þe þrid tyme ȝit his felawe
Come as he þoght I am now I slowe
Byhold my blody wondys depe and wide
Arise vp erly in þe morne tyde
And at þe westgate of þe toūn quod he
A cartful of dunge þere shalt þu see
In wiche his body is hid ful pꝰeruyly
Do þilke cart a rest boldly
My gold caused my mordre soth to sayn
And told hym euꝰery poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pitously face pale of hewe
And truste wel his dreme he fond ful trewe
For on þe morne as sone as it was daye
To his felawes In he toke þe waie
And when he come to þis oxe stalle
Aftꝰer his felaw he by gan calle
The Ostelere vnswerd hym a none
And saide sir ȝoure felaw is gone
As sone as day he went out of toūn
Þis man can falle in grete suspicion
Remembryng on his dremes þat he mette
And forth he goth no lengꝰer wold he lette
Vnto þe westegate of þe toūn ⁊ fonde
A . donge carte as he went to dong þe lond
Þat was araied in þe same wise
As ȝe han herd þe dede man devise
And with an hardi herte he can to crie
Vengeance austice of þis vilanye
Myn felow murdred is þis same nyght
And in þis Cart he lieth gapyng vp right
Þe dede man þat murdred was al newe
O blisful god þat art so Iuste and trewe
Lo how þat þu be wreiest mordre alle way
Mordre wol oute þat se we day by day
Mordre is so wlatsome and so abhōmiable
To god þat is so Iuste and resonable
Þat he ne wille suffre it helid be
Þeigh it a bide a ȝer or two or þre
Mordre wole out þis is myn conclusion
And right a non mynystres of þe toūn
Hath hent þe Cartꝰer and sore hym peyned
And eke þe Osteler so ferre engyned
Þat þei be knew her wickednes anon
And were hangid by the nekke bon
Here may men se þat dremes ben to drede
And certes in þe same boke I rede
Right in þe next Chapitre I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haue I Ioy or blis
Two men þat wolden haue passed þe see
For certeyn cause in to a ferre contre
If þat þe wynde nad but contrarie
Þat made hem in a Cite for to tarie
Þat stode ful mery vpon h a hauen side
But on a day a ȝenst þe Evyn tide
Þe wynd can chaunge and blow as hym liste
Iolyf and glad þei wenten vnto reste
And Casten hem ful ȝerly for to saile
But herken þat oo man felle in grete ꝑperile
That oo of hem in slepyng as he lay
Hym mette a wonder dreme a ȝenst þe day
Hym þoght a man stode by his beddes side
And hym comaunded þat he shuld abide
And said hym þus if þu to morow wende
Thou shalt be dreyned my tale is at an ende
He wooke and told his felow what he mette
And praide hym his viage for to lette
As for þat day he praide hym for to abide
His felaw þat lay by his beddes side
Gan for to lawgh and scorned hym ful faste
No drem quod he may myn hert agaste
Þat I wolle lette for to do my thinges
I sette noght a straw by dremynges
For sweues ben but vanitees and Iapes
Men dreme alway of owles and apes
And of mony a mase þer wtith alle
Men dremen of þing þat neuꝰer was or ne shal
But sithyns I se þu wolt here a bide
And þus wilfully for slewþen þi tide
God wotte it rewith me ⁊ haue gode day
And þus he toke his leue and went his way
And er þat he hadd half his cours I sailed
Note I not whi ne what meschance it ayled
But casuelly þe shippes botm rent
And shippe and man vnder þe watꝰer went
In sight of Other shippes hym byside
That with hym seiled at þe same tide
And therfore he saide ꝑpertelote so dere
By suche ensamples old mayst þu lere
Þat noman shuld be to recheles
Of dremes for I say the douteles
Þat mony a dreme ful sore is for to drede
Lo in þe lif of seyn kenelme I rede
Þat was kenulphus sone þe noble kyng
Of Mercenrike how kenelme mete a thing
A luytel er he was mordred on a day
His mordre in his avision he say
His norice hym expowned euꝰerydel
His sweuen and bade hym for to kepe it hym welle
For treson but he was seuen ȝer old
And therfore litul tale hathe he told
Of any dreme so holly was his hert
By god I hadde neuꝰer þan my shert
Þat ȝe hadd herd his legend as haue I
Dame ꝑpertelote I say ȝow trewly
Macrobeus þat writte þe avision
In affrike of worthi Ciprion
Affermeth dremes and saith þat þer ben
Warnyng of þinges þat men aftꝰer seen
And forthermore I pray ȝow lokeþ welle
Þe Old testament of Danyel
Ȝif he held dremes of any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and ȝe shullen se
Whether dremes ben somtyme I say not alle
Warnyng of þinges þat shulles aftꝰer falle
Loke eke of Egipte þe kyng daun pharao
His baker and his boteler also
Wher þei ne felt non effecte in dremes
Who so wold se the þe acte of sondry remes
May reden of dremes mony a wonder þing
Lo Cresus wiche þat was of lide kyng
Mette he noght þat he satte vpon a tre
Wiche signified þat he an honged shuld be
Lo here a dromacha Ectors wif
Þat day þat Ector shuld lete his lif
She dremed on þe same nyght byforne
Hou þat þe lif of Ector shuld be lorne
If þilke day he went in to bataile
She warned hym but it myght not a vaile
He wente for to fighten neuꝰer þe lees
But he was slayn of Achilles
But þilke tale is alle to long to telle
And eke it is nyghe day I may not dwelle
Shortly I say as for conclusion
Þat I shal haue of þis a vision
Of aduꝰersites and I say forthermore
Þat I ne wille telle of laxatifs no store
For þei ben venymous I wot right welle
I hem defie I loue hem neuꝰer a del
Lo let vs speke of myrthe ⁊ stynt al þis
Madame ꝑpertelote so haue I blis
Of o thing god hath sent me large grace
For when I see þe beaute of ȝoure face
Ȝe ben so scarlet rede a boute ȝoure eyȝen
Hit makith alle my drede for to deien
For also siker as in principio
Mulier est hōmis confusio
Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Woman is mannys Ioy ⁊ his blis
For when I fele a nyght ȝoure soft side
Alle be it þat I may not on ȝow ride
For þat oure ꝑperche is made so nare alas
I am so ful of Ioy ⁊ solas
Þat I defie bothe sweuen and dreme
And with þat word I flye done fro þe beem
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a chukke he gan hem forthe to calle
For he hade fonde a corne lay in þe ȝerd
Real he was nomore a ferd
He fethert ꝑpertelote twenty tyme
And trade as oft er it was pirime
He logith as it were a grym lion
And on his toes he romed vp ⁊ doūn
Hym deigned not to sette his feete on gronde
Ay chokked he when he hadd a corne I fonde
And to hym þanne ranne his wyfes alle
Thus roiall as a prynce in his halle
Leue I this chaunteclere in his pasture
And aftꝰer wole I telle of his aduenture
When þe monthe in wiche þe word bygan
That hight Marche when god first made man
Was complete and passed were also
Sithens Marche by gan thritti daies ⁊ two
By felle þat chauntecler in his piride
His seuyn wyfes walkyng hym byside
Cast vp his eyȝen to þe bright sonne
That in þe signe of taurꝭes was ronne
Twenti degrees and oon and somwhat more
He knew by kynd by none other lore
Þat it was pirime he crew wtith blisful steuen
Þe sonne he saide is clomben vpon heuen
Fourti degrees and oon ⁊ som what more Iwis
Ma dame ꝑpertelote my worldes blis
Herke how þise blisful briddes syng
And se þe fresshe floures how þei spryng
Ful is myn hert of Reuel ⁊ of solas
But sodeynly hym felle a sorowful caas
For euꝰer þe lattꝰer ende of Ioy is sone a gone
And comonly ofte tyme it falleþ so
And ȝif Arthour coude faire endite
He in a cronycle my sauely write
As for a souerayn notabilite
Now euꝰery wiseman nou hekene me
This story is als trew I vndertake
As is þe boke of launcelot de lake
Þat wōmmen held in ful grete reuꝰerence
Now wolle I turne a ȝeyn to my sentence
A . Col foxe ful of sleight and iniquite
That in þe groue hadde woned ȝeres tre
By highe ymaginacion a forne caste
Þe same nyȝt þurghe oute þe hogges braste
In to þe ȝerd þer chante clere þe faire
Was wont and eke his wyfes to repaire
And in a bedde of wortes stille he lay
Til it was passed vnderne of þe day
Waytyng his tyme on chanteclere to falle
As gladly done þise homicides alle
Þat in a waite ligge to murdre men
O false murdourer roukyn in þi den
O new scariote and new geniloūn
False dissimulor o greke Synoūn
Þat broght troy alle vtterly to sorow
O chauntecler o cursed be þat morewe
Þat þu in þe ȝerd fle fro þe bemes
Þu were ful wel I warned by thi dremes
That ilke day was ꝑperilous to þe
But þat at god a fore wote mote nedes be
Afftꝰer þe opynyon of certeyn clerkes
Wittenes on hym þat any clerke is
Þat in scole grete altꝰercacion
In þis mater and grete disputacion
And hath ben of an hundred þousand men
But I ne can bulte it to þe bren
As can þe holy doctour Augustyn
Or boece or þe Buschope Bradwardyn
Wether þat goddes wille a fore wetyng
Streyneth me nedly for to do a thing
Nedely clepe I simple necessite
Or elles if þe fre choise be granted me
To do þat same þing or to do it noght
Þogh god forwote it er it was wroght
Or of his wetyng streyneth neuꝰer a dele
But by necessite condicionele
I wole note haue to done of suche matere
My tale is of a Cokke as ȝe shulle here
Þat toke his conseil of his wif wtith sorowe
To walken in þe ȝerd vpon þe morewe
Þat he had mette þe dreme þat I ȝow told
Wymmen conseil ben ful ofte cold
Wymens conseil broght vs first to wo
And made Adam fro paradys to go
Ther as he was ful mery ⁊ welle at ese
But for I not whom I myght displese
If I conseil of wōmmen wold blame
Passe ouꝰer for I said it in my game
Rede Auctours where þei trete of suche matere
And what þei sayn of women here
Thise ben þe Cokkes wordes ⁊ not myne
I con non harme of no wōmman devyne
Faire in þe sande to bathe hir meryly
Lythe ꝑpertelote and hir sustres by
A ȝen þe sonne and chauntclere so fre
Sang merier þan þe mere maide in þe se
For phisialogus saith witterly
How þat þei syngen wel ⁊ merily
And so by felle as he caste his eiȝe
Amonges þe wortes vpon a buttꝰerflie
He was warre of þis fox þtat lay ful lowe
No þing ne lust hym þan for to crowe
But cried a non Cok Cok ⁊ vp stert
As a man þat was a fraied in his hert
For naturely a best desirith to fle
For his contrarie if he may it se
Þei he hadd neuꝰer seie it erst wtith his eie
This Chauntecler when he can hym aspie
He wold haue fled but þat þe fox a none
Saide Gentil sir alas what wole ȝe done
Ben ȝe afraied of þat am ȝoure frende
Certes sir þan be ȝe vn hend
Ȝif I to ȝow wole harme or vilanye
I am not come ȝoure conseil to aspie
But trewly þe cause of my comyng
Was only to herken how þat ȝe syng
For trewly ȝe han as merie a steuen
As aungel hath þat is in heuen
Þerwith ȝe haue in musike more felyng
Þanne hade boys or any þat con syng
Myn lord ȝoure fader god his soule blesse
And eke ȝoure moder of his gentilnesse
Han in myn hous I ben to ȝow grete ese
And certes sir right fayn wold I ȝow plese
But for men speken of synkyn I wol sayn
So mote I broke myn eyen tweie
Sauf ȝe I ne herd neuꝰer man so syng
As did ȝoure fader in þe mornyng
Certes it was of hert alle þat he sang
And for to make his vois þe more strang
He wold so peyne hym þat wtith both his eyȝen
He moste wynke so loude he dide crien
And stonden on his typtos ther with alle alle
And strege forth his l nekke long ⁊ smalle
And eke he was of suche discrecion
Þat þer nas no man in no region
Þat hym in song or wisdom myght passe
I haue wel red daun burnel þer asse
A mong his vers þer was a cok
For a preostes sone ȝaf hym a knok
Vpon his legg whiles he was ȝong ⁊ nyce
He made hym for to lese his bnfice
But certes þer is no comꝑperison
By twix þe wisdom ⁊ discrecion
Of ȝoure fader and subtilite
Now syngith sir for seynt Charite
Lete se con ȝe ȝoure fader conterfete
This Chauntecler his wynges gan to bete
As man þat coude his treson not aspie
So was he rauysshed with his flaterie
Alas ȝe lordes mony a fals flatour
Is in ȝoure court as mony losyngrour
Þat plesen ȝou more by my feithe
Þan he þat sothefastnes vnto ȝow seithe
Redith ecclesiastre of flaterie
Beth warre ȝe lordes of ȝer trecherie
Þis Chauntecler stode hyghe vpon his toos
Strechyng his nekke l and held his eyen cloos
And gan to crow loude for þe nones
And daun Russell stert vp alle a tones
And by þe gargate hent Chaunteclere
And on his bak toward wodde hym bere
For ȝit was þer no man hym sewed
O destynye þat may not ben eschewed
Alas þat chauntecler felle fro þe bemes
Alas his wif ne roght noght of dremes
And on a friday fel al þis meschance
O venus þat art goddes of plesance
Sythyns þat þi seruaunt was þis Chaunteclere
And in þi seruyse did alle his powere
More for delite þan for þe world multeplie
Whi woldest þu suffre on þi day to die
O gaufrede dere maister souerayne
That when þi worthi go kyng Richard was slayn
With shotte compleynest his deth so sore
Whi ne hadd I now þyn sentence ⁊ þyn lore
The freday for to chide as deden ȝe
For on a friday shortly slayn was he
Then wold I shew ȝow how þat I coude pleyne
For Chanteclere and for his peyne
Certes suche crie ne lamentacion
Was of ladies made when yleon
Was wonne and pirrus with his streigh swird
When he hent kyng pryan by the berd
And slayn hym as saide Enneydos
As maden alle þe hennes in þe cloos
When þai hade saie of Chanteclere þe sight
But souꝰeraynly dame ꝑpertelot shright
Welle ludder þen did hasdrubaldes wif
Whan þat hir husbond had lost hys lif
And þat þe Romayns had brent Carttage
Sho was so ful of tourment ⁊ of rage
That wilfully in to þe fuyre she stert
And brent hir self with a stidfast hert
O woful hennes right so crid ȝe
As wen þat Nero brent þe Cite
Of Rome criden þe Senatoures wyfes
For þat her husbondes shuld lese her lyfes
With outen gilt Nero hath hem slayn
Now wolle I torne to my tale a ȝayne
This sely widow and hir doghtres two
Herden þe hennes crien and maken woo
And out at þe dore sterten þei a non
And sauhe þe fox toward þe groue gone
And bare vp his bak þe Cok a waye
And crieden on harow and weel a way
A ha þe foxe and aftꝰer hym þai ran
And eke with staves mony an other man
Ranne Colle oure dogge Talbot ⁊ garlond
And Malkyn with hir distaf in hir hond
Ranne Cow and Calf and eke þe verray hogges
Sore a ferd for berkyng of þe dogges
And shotyng of men and of wōmmen eke
Þei ran so her hert þei þoght to breke
Þei ȝelden as fendes done in helle
Þe dogges criden as men wold hem quelle
Out of þe hyves came þe swarme of bes
Þe gees for fere floen ouꝰer þe trees
So hidous was þe noyce a bndicite
Certes he Iakk straw and his menye
Ne made neuꝰer shotes half so shrille
Whan þat þei wold any flemyng kille
As þat ilke day was made vpon þe fox
Of bras þei broght bemes ⁊ of box
Of horne and bone in wiche þei pouped
And þer with alle þei schiched and shouted
Hit semed as þat heuen shuld falle
Now god I pray ȝow herkenyth alle
Lo how fortune turneth sodeynly
The hope and eke pride of her envie
Þis Cok þat lay vpon þis fox bakke
In alle alle his drede vnto þe fox spake
And saide sir ȝif I were as ȝe
Ȝet shuld I say as wys god helpe me
Turneþ a ȝeyn ȝe proude Cherles alle
A verrai pestelance vpon ȝow falle
Now am I come vnto þis wode side
Maugray ȝore hede þe Cok shal here abide
I wolle hym ete in feith ⁊ þat a noon
Þe fox vnswared in feith it shal be done
And he spake þat word al sodenly
This Cok brake from his mouthe delyuꝰerly
And hygh vpon a tre he fleigh a noon
And when þe fox saw þat he was gone
Alas quod he o chauntecler alas
I haue quod he to ȝow done a trespas
In as moche as I made ȝow a ferde
When I ȝow hent and broght out of þe ȝerd
But sir I dide it noght in no wicked entent
Cometh done and I shal telle ȝow what ment
I shal say soth so god helpe me so
Nay þan quod he I shrew vs both two
And first I shrew my self both blode ⁊ bones
Ȝif þou bygile me oftꝰer þan ones
Þou shalt nomore with thyn flaterie
Do me to synge and wynke wtith myn Eye
For he þat wynkith when he shuld see
As wisly god let hym neuꝰer the
Nay quod þe fox god ȝif hym meschance
Þat is so vndescrete of gouꝰernance
Þat Iangleþ when he shuld haue pees
Lo suche it is for to be recheles
And necligent ⁊ trusteþ on flaterie
But ȝe þat holden þis tale a folie
As of a fox of a Cok ⁊ of a henne
Takeþ þe moralite good men
For seyn poule saith þ alle þtat writen is
To oure doctryne hit is I writen I wis
Takeþ þe froit ⁊ leteþ þe chaf be stille
Nou good god if þat it be þi wille
As seit my lord so make vs alle gode men
And bryng vs alle to his highe blysse amen

l.hi: Here endith þe Nonne preostes tale

div.l: (base) And here folweth the prologe of the Manciples tale
(base) Woot ye nat where ther stant a litel town
(base) Which that clepid is Bobbe vpanddown
(base) Vnder the Blee in Caunterbury weye
(base) Ther gan oure hoost for to iape and pleye
(base) And seyde sires what Don is in the Myre
(base) Is ther no man for preyere ne for hyre
(base) That wole awake oure felawe al bihynde
(base) A theef myghte hym ful lightly robbe and bynde
(base) Se how he nappeth se how for Cokkes bones
(base) That he wol falle from his hors atones
(base) Is that a Cook of Londoun with meschaunce
(base) Do hym come forth he knoweth his penaunce
(base) For he shal telle a tale by my fey
(base) Althogh it be nat worth a botel hey
(base) Awake thow Cook quod he god yeue thee sorwe
(base) What eyleth thee to slepe by the morwe
(base) Hastow had fleen al nyght or artow dronke
(base) Or hastow with som quene al nyght yswonke
(base) So that thow mayst nat holden vp thyn heed
(base) This Cook that was ful pale and no thyng reed
(base) Seyde to oure hoost so god my soule blesse
(base) As ther is falle on me swich heuynesse
(base) Noot I nat why that me were leuere slepe
(base) Than the beste galoun wyn in Chepe
(base) Wel quod the Manciple if it may don ese
(base) To thee sir Cook and to no wight displese
(base) Which that here rideth in this compaignye
(base) And that oure hoost wole of his curteisye
(base) I wole as now excuse thee of thy tale
(base) For in good feith thy visage is ful pale
(base) Thyne eyen daswen eek as that me thynketh
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh
(base) That sheweth wel thow art nat wel disposed
(base) Of me certeyn thow shalt nat ben yglosed
(base) Se how he ganeth lo this dronken wight
(base) As though he wolde swolwe vs anon right
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man by thy fader kyn
(base) The deuel of helle sette his foot ther yn
(base) Thy cursed breeth infecte wol vs alle
(base) Fy stynkynge swyn fy foule mote thee falle
(base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan
(base) Ther to me thynketh ye ben wel yshape
(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw
(base) And on the Manciple bigan he nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste
(base) Wher as he lay til that men vp hym took
(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his Sadel
(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro
(base) To lifte hym vp and muchel care and wo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple thanne spak oure hoost
(base) By cause drynke hath domynacioun
(base) Vpon this man by my sauacioun
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wolde his tale
(base) For were it wyn or old or moisty Ale
(base) That he hath dronke he speketh in his nose
(base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do moore than ynow
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To kepen hym and his capil out of the Slow
(base) And if he falle from his capil eft soone
(base) Than shal we alle haue ynow to doone
(base) In liftynge vp his heuy dronken cors
(base) Telle on thy tale of hym make I no fors
(base) But yet Manciple in feith thow art to nyce
(base) Thus openly repreue hym of his vice
(base) Another day he wole par auenture
(base) Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges
(base) That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
(base) No quod the Manciple that were a gret mescheef
(base) So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare
(base) Yet hadde I leuere payen for the Mare
(base) Which he rit on than he sholde with me stryue
(base) I wol nat wrathe hym also mote I thryue
(base) That that I spak I seyde it in my bourde
(base) And wite what I haue here in a gourde
(base) A draughte of wyn ye of a rype grape
(base) And right anon ye shul seen a good Iape
(base) This Cook shal drynke ther of if I may
(base) Vp peyne of deeth he wol nat seye me nay
(base) And certeynly to tellen as it was
(base) Of this vessel the Cook drank faste allas
(base) What neded it he drank ynow biforn
(base) And whan he hadde powped in this horn
(base) To the Manciple he took the gourde agayn
(base) And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn
(base) And thanked hym in swich wise as he kowde
(base) Thanne gan oure hoost to laughen wonder lowde
